The current concern must therefore not make us forget that serious health problems are currently available to prevention through vaccination, against which we still have to fight against reluctance.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Commissioner, as you have indicated, there is still a great deal of uncertainty about this coronavirus. First, on the number of people infected. When we look at the numbers, the Chinese tell us about 6,000 people infected, the University of Hong Kong tells us about 40,000. Then, on his contagion. Is it really more contagious than other viruses? We realize that this is not really the case. Is it more deadly than other viruses? We see that in relation to the flu, it is not. Will it mutate more than others? Right now, that is not really the case either. So I agree with my colleague, let us stop being afraid and I would like to convey a message: let us stop stigmatizing the Chinese and Asian community. As you have indicated, we really need to focus on a research policy, on a policy of cooperation between states and above all on good information from the population, because we must not fall into an irrational panic. Finally, we must remember that in France, there are between 600 and 700 people who die each year from forms of coronavirus.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: On behalf of the ID Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the coronavirus is a serious matter: we are talking about 6 000 infections, SARS has been overcome, 132 dead and the virus has also entered Europe.  So, you see, in this place where we sovereignists have been called a virus, you have said that you are making a cordon sanitary cord towards us, and now that there is a real virus, Europe is being disunited and lagging behind. Disunited because some countries attract their compatriots, others do not. Some airlines, such as British Airways and Lufthansa, block flights, others do not. Other countries have even blocked entry, others have not.  Late because it is clear that we need to work together with the World Health Organisation, which has only now raised the level of high risk assessment, and we need to work with them to find the vaccine as quickly as possible.  Finally, it is clear that the Chinese Government must also intervene in the sanitary and hygienic conditions of the markets, not least because it is very likely that this virus, like SARS, has developed in areas and markets where wild animals are sold and eaten, including bats and snakes.

name: Joanna KOPCIŃSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Based on recent experience with SARS and MERS (both coronavirus), the European Union is familiar with such infections. We have a strong enough medical infrastructure to be able to combat the escalation of these infections. I welcome the work carried out by ECDC and PREPARE and the exchange of monitoring and risk assessment data with the Member States. Nevertheless, we must remain vigilant. Coronavirus can be transferred from person to person, and the length of the incubation period of the virus can vary.  Can the Commission provide information on when updated risk assessments will be published that take these facts into account? Yesterday, at the request of France, the EU Civil Protection Mechanism was launched. Given the dynamic situation, can the Council and the Commission provide Parliament with up-to-date information on the Emergency Response Coordination Centre and its cooperation with Member State governments on coordinating the repatriation of European Union citizens and possible subsequent quarantine periods?

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Members of the Council, I am sure we can agree that this is not the first or unfortunately the last epidemic we are dealing with here. But I agree with my colleagues that we should not panic, although infectious diseases are certainly not to be underestimated. In any case, I hope that this will remain the case and that the information from doctors that there are fewer infected and the infection appears to be weaker compared to SARS will remain so.  What I do not think we should underestimate, too, and I am glad that the mechanisms at almost all European airports have worked, is screening at the airports themselves. We should have access to rapid action, where we can basically detain these patients and start treating them immediately so that they do not bring us the virus any further. Likewise, rapid diagnosis can help us greatly. But I do want to conclude by saying this – let us trust the system we have set up. Our ECDC and WHO are monitoring the situation and are ready to act. They seem to respect the government's recommendations, and I firmly believe that this will continue to be the case, and I thank the Commissioner for her active assistance.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: Mr President, first of all, despite the fact that, as colleagues have already said, I do not yet know much or are not sure, i would like to congratulate the European Commission. Because I have seen a Commission that reacts quickly, which has also offered, for example, to jointly carry out and coordinate the repatriation of people. This is particularly important for small countries. We haven't seen such a quick response in previous cases, so that's good.  I have a number of questions for the Commission on the development of a vaccine. This is being developed, but is it also happening in a coordinated way in Europe? And once that vaccine is in hand, is the Commission also intending and prepared to use, for example, shortened authorisation and authorisation procedures? Once that vaccine is in place, it's very important to get it to market quickly. And, for example, does the Commission also recommend that virus inhibitors should be stocked at the moment?  and maybe then one request to the Commissioner from a personal experience: Commissioner, if you could please coordinate the advice that Member States give to people who have questions. When the Mexican flu came to Europe and people were concerned, I was at the time pregnant in Belgium, and in the Netherlands obviously, and in Belgium I got the advice to get vaccinated and in the Netherlands I got the advice to absolutely don't get a vaccination. So that makes people very insecure and if you could help take these concerns away among Europeans that would be highly appreciated.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent At the beginning of the year, a new coronavirus was confirmed, now in China. The serious thing is that it can infect people. A new virus always leads to anxiety and in some cases also panic. I therefore welcome the clear leadership that the WHO has also taken with China – this to stop the spread of the virus. That's good. It is important that the international community and the countries concerned are quick and transparent with information and facts about the spread of infection.  It is now very important that we and our Member States, our various governments and ministers make every contribution to preventing an outbreak in Europe. It is never possible to underestimate the importance of accurate and relevant information for all our citizens. Knowledge provides security, and knowledge leads to the right actions and the right actions. We have medical experts who judge Europe's health care good, but we must not sit back. We're going to do everything we can. The public health of our citizens is important, and there we have a responsibility.

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, sometimes I feel that history repeats itself when I see citizens who are going to pharmacies to buy protective masks, who buy disinfectant gel and use it every five minutes and who, it seems, always expect a new epidemic. SARS syndrome in 2003; Ebola in 2014; Zika, in 2015, and now, in 2020, coronavirus.  In the age of climate change, the only constant is the increasing change and virulence of pandemics. Our role is to show leadership and method, a concrete plan for what we already know is happening.  Colleagues, we have the opportunity to strengthen RescEU for an entire generation. Let us equip the programme with a serious supply of medicines and a rapid joint procurement procedure. We have to be prepared tomorrow as we would have liked to be today. European citizens expect a shield from Europe for life and health.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, I think that this debate has shown us that, in cases like this, we need a strong common European response, a common European Union healthcare policy. Unfortunately, we know that – according to Article 168 – possibilities to have a common EU policy in this area are very limited. So my question to you is this: does this outbreak show us that the European Union needs more powers in the area of healthcare to combat these kinds of threats?

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Sokol, you’re preaching to the converted: you know we want this; you know we need this; you know that Europe needs to ‘send a man to the moon’ in the form of fighting cancer. So yes, I do think that we need not only more competence, but also to use what we already have: to use Article 168, to use the common market, to use every exception we can get to bring health policy forward for one simple reason: because European citizens accept and want this very much. So, definitely, yes.

name: Francisco GUERREIRO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, from December 2019 to the day to date more than 6,000 people have been infected with the corona virus and more than 100 have died because of its effects. Even though the outbreak is more intense in China, the virus has already reached the United States of America, Canada, Australia and even here, Europe. On this issue we must not forget that China is the main source of imports from the European Union, and we in the EU follow the recommendations of the World Health Organisation, thus achieving high standards of food safety and quality. China, on the other hand, is not governed by the same standards. However, it continues to benefit from a privileged commercial opening on the part of this European Union. In exchange for our openness it seems that we have now received a deadly virus, which is not only affecting the Chinese but much of the world. China's irresponsibility in terms of food safety and hygiene must be strongly questioned by this European Union.

name: Simona BALDASSARRE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the news we have received in recent days about the coronavirus epidemic is increasingly worrying and often contradictory. We are at 132 dead, more than 6 000 confirmed cases and almost 10 000 suspects.  The Ivory Coast Health Minister reported that a thirty-four-year-old woman from Beijing was hospitalized with coronavirus-like symptoms and many African states then issued restrictions on travelers. But is there control over who enters Europe from third countries? Furthermore, who controls the irregular immigration flows that arrive on European shores? Who imposes the necessary forty? Furthermore, I would like to point out that the current protocol for verifying the spot temperature of incoming tourists is insufficient and dangerous, both because of the inaccuracy of the skin measurement and because it does not take into account the incubation period. The Commission should require all States to check that travellers have not resided in infected areas, at least in the previous two weeks, or impose an equivalent quarantine period.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Mr President, epidemics and viruses do not understand borders and therefore the coronavirus epidemic continues to spread in China.  Europe has always distinguished itself by dealing with health emergencies around the world, in early detection and prevention. Seventeen years after the epidemic of acute breathing syndrome, lessons learned need to be put in place to counteract this epidemic. The European Union is an example in the world of solidarity, cooperation, efficiency, but we are also leaders in the world in prevention and health care. We therefore have an obligation to support any country in difficulty, in respect of those principles of solidarity and cooperation in which the European Union has been built, and we must therefore also require China transparency and information. Because we believe that the European Union should activate the European Emergency Response Coordination Centre to facilitate these assistance and advisory actions to China, as well as to other affected countries, and also to be able to coordinate early response in Member States and prevention in the Member States. And we need to get to work, coordinated by the European Commission and, of course, with the collaboration of WHO.  Europe must ensure the defence of the public health of its citizens, as well as the citizens of the rest of the world. And that is why we need to put ourselves at the front line in organizing a coordinated response to the health emergency, which can become global.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Well, if we as MEPs ever needed a reminder that we are dealing with matters of life and death, this is it. I’m a physician by training and there are three aspects I want to stress. Europe needs to be calm, united and prepared, because in a crisis situation trust in our institutions is paramount, and I’m very worried to see the legitimate fears of the public being manipulated and geared towards hate-mongering. Descending to xenophobia against Chinese, Europeans, visitors and immigrants leads absolutely nowhere. If there is an irresponsible way of dealing with a crisis, well, this is it.  And this challenge highlights also how interdependent we are in Europe, because pandemics know no borders and, unfortunately, there are great inequalities between the healthcare systems of our Member States. We have to help each other. Less developed regions need European help to take the necessary precautionary measures. If one Member State is overburdened, that has an impact on every single Member State. So a crisis like this makes it crystal clear that solidarity is in the interest of all of us.

name: Luisa REGIMENTI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, as a doctor, I am deeply concerned about the oil-squid spread of coronavirus, the global risk of which, by the same admission as the World Health Organisation, is considered high.  We are facing a worldwide threat of great proportion and extreme gravity. The virus is strengthening and is also spreadable through asymptomatic subjects. To date, numerous cases of contagion have also been found in Europe.  The actions taken so far by the European Commission, although appropriate, are not enough to protect our citizens from a powerful virus of which we do not have clear information on symptoms and epidemiological pathways. I believe it is extremely urgent and important for the European Union to urge the World Health Organisation to declare an international health emergency and, consequently, to take immediate health measures which the situation requires, not least, if necessary, the temporary closure of China's borders, with the suspension of imports of all potential vehicles of infection.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The situation we are facing today is certainly serious. We must not underestimate it, we must not wonder when the first or next case of infection will occur in our state, in our city. Today's world without borders is particularly conducive to such fears.  I call on the European Commission to join forces. Together, we need to find answers to difficult questions. Are European laboratories prepared for rapid virus identification? Are European hospitals ready for adequate and effective treatment of infected patients? Are there and are procedures in place to protect healthcare professionals? name: Nicolás GONZÁLEZ CASARES
text: – Mr President, I would tell the Commission and the Council that, above all, seriousness, without alarmism, but seriousness in communication. We have many citizens of the European Union living in Asia and we also have great international trade; therefore, we have to be serious in communication.  I think we've learned from previous crises and we have prior knowledge. Let's get it going and use it. Of course, coordination between Member States and within the European Union is essential. We have common borders and we must control them, but, as I say, without falling into alarmism.  Health workers in the European Union and our emergency services have learned from previous crises; therefore, we have that knowledge that will allow us not to fall into alarmisms. And I'm also talking about repatriations. It is not the same to repatriate people who are living outside and who are on alert as to people who have and have symptoms: we must know how to differentiate and inform; let's put protocols in place and communicate them well.

name: Andreas GLÜCK
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report I think it is right that a large part of the health sector should be regulated by the nation states. However, there are some areas where Europe needs to become stronger, particularly in the area of drug approval and hygiene. Just before that, I spoke to Professor Kremsner from the University of Tübingen – where I studied medicine – and he confirmed to me that a great deal is actually going well at European level, but not everything is perfect. Commissioner Kyriakides has mentioned two points which I would like to underline. On the one hand, we need to strengthen the ECDC – financially but also with its competences. Compared to the American CDC, the ECDC leads a poverty existence. And the second is that, in emergencies, the authorisation of medicines must also be less bureaucratic. To this end, we would like to see not only phase 3 studies carried out by the European Medicines Agency, but also phase 1 and 2 studies in order to save time here. In times of nova corona, we say it clearly: Europe is quite well when it comes to public health, but we can get a lot better, so let's make it so.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Dear Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. In recent weeks, there have been extremely worrying reports of the spread of the coronavirus, which has recently been identified in China as severe pneumonia. I consider it of the utmost importance that Member States have up-to-date and real information and that the recommendations of the World Health Organisation and EU specialisation agencies are constantly monitored and that precautionary decisions are taken accordingly. As our airports are the gateway to Europe for Chinese travelers, if any official action is ordered, our airports should have all the necessary equipment and equipment to meet their standards and support the work of the authorities. I believe that the protection of our citizens first. Coordination is very important now, which is why I am asking the European Commission to constantly analyse the situation and make the necessary proposals to the Member States.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Mr President, it is official. Even if we don't like it, it's official. The new coronavirus is now also threatening Europe. Four cases are in France and four in Germany, and prevention measures are extremely important.  I am a doctor, an emergency doctor in Iaşi, Romania, at the "Nicolae Oblu" Emergency Clinical Hospital, and I believe that at this time, my honour, the Commission and the Council, it is extremely important to put in place a unified intervention plan to achieve three things that can prevent the spread of this type of virus.  Firstly, unitary prevention measures at European level. Secondly, unitary active monitoring measures and yes, the rapid alert system can be a solution. Thirdly, the preparation for possible intervention, and the RescEU and the European Civil Protection Mechanism are just a few elements of this whole, and I believe that the provision of medicines and a mobile medical team at European level can be solutions at any time in such a crisis situation.  In addition, I remind you that the virus has overcome three major barriers. First of all, it was initially said that it is a zoonosis, that it cannot be transmitted from animals to humans, and here it is transmitted, and at the moment we see that there are many cases at European level, as we say... (The President has withdrawn the speaker's word).

name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
text: – Mr President, the new outbreak of coronavirus demonstrates once again the importance of adequate funding of science as well as international cooperation. In different parts of the world several teams are already working on a vaccine for this virus and we have reason to believe that the solution may come faster than in 2003 when we faced the Coronavirus SARS. It's worth being prepared, it's worth investing in science. It was thanks to funds provided by Horizon 2020 that an Ebola vaccine was obtained following the outbreak of the disease in 2014. This development has allowed us to save many lives around the world. The added value of investment in science becomes very evident when the results arise, but these only appear when there is a solid, continued and sustainable bet.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: – Mr President-in-Office, Commissioner, representatives of the Council.  Reports of how coronavirus is spreading are certainly worrying. What I would like to emphasise is, above all, that this once again shows how we need to act in a thoughtful and coordinated manner. So that the added value of the European Union is in the coordination and cooperation of the members.  In view of this, I have also given an urgent question to the Council, but this is not intended to create an emergency, panic or spread intolerance, but above all a call for us to act in a coordinated manner.  I am pleased by the proactive role of the European Commission, including at operational level, both in the area of health and crisis management, and the fact that we have mechanisms on which we can rely, that is, civil protections that are developed, they still need to be adequately materially supported in order to react properly to the situation before the will of the States to ...  (The president turned off the microphone.)

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, my intervention is very short. Indeed, we are all concerned, Europe is concerned about this virus and the danger comes precisely from the fact that it is a virus that is spreading very rapidly.  I congratulate the Commission and the Council for acting firmly, quickly, communicating, but I feel that you need to do more precisely to inform citizens, especially citizens in vulnerable areas. I think it is good to take it to the next level, through which you prepare, through the media, campaigns to encourage citizens to protect themselves. Hygiene, prevention are essential things in times of such crisis.

name: Manuel PIZARRO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the coronavirus epidemic does not justify panic, but justifies a concern and concerted attitude. More than 100 people have died, there are cases diagnosed in eighteen different countries. We all know that the epidemic started in China, which is where its most worrying point is, and we all also know that Taiwan is a very important hub in that geographical area of East Asia.  That is why, in my view, the news coming that Taiwanese experts are not included in the meeting of high-level experts convened by the World Health Organization is very worrying. Geopolitical considerations cannot be more relevant than the protection of public health and health for all citizens of the world, and I would like to know what the European institutions, and in particular the European Commission, think to ensure that Taiwan is actively involved in combating this epidemic, which is also essential for us European.

name: Liudas MAŽYLIS
text: – Mr President, the coronavirus, despite the assumptions, is coming. Epidemiologically, there's nothing surprising about that. It is estimated that one infected spreads the infection on average two and a half of the surrounding ones, so to cut off the spread chain, it is necessary to isolate 60% of those who have experienced contact. And, as was expected, in China this virus was not isolated. Historically, there have been examples of such. 100 years ago there was a Spanish virus, whose experience may not be so important to us, but in the 21st century we encountered the SARS virus, and that experience is accumulated. I believe that the plan of measures for professionals is fundamentally clear. I would agree that information campaigns are very important in the short term, and in the long term, I agree with those who are talking about increased investment in research.

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – It’s an interesting debate. I will try to touch on as many questions as possible. I hope, in the way that I spoke at the beginning, I did not appear to stir up panic. This was not the intention, and as Veronique Trillet-Lenoir has said, we should not create panic. But we need to balance that with being vigilant and carefully monitoring a changing situation, which is what we have at the moment. There are many uncertainties – many of you have mentioned this. The WHO has issued guidelines, together with ECDC, for travel, and I would also like to add here that we really don’t have any indications, as has been said by some colleagues and by Madam Montserrat, that China is not giving all the necessary information. In fact, the WHO General Director was there two days ago and has already briefed us on what the situation is. It’s obvious that we need to have global cooperation and we need to have constant updates. We do need to be very careful that we are speaking with one clear voice, and this is exactly what we are trying to do in our coordinating role as a Commission, to ensure that ECDC info and WHO information reaches the Member States. In terms of vaccinations, the Commission is launching a call to develop a vaccine as we speak, and the European Medicines Authority can authorise a fast-track procedure if this is found. There is concern among European citizens, and WHO and ECDC have given clear guidelines on travel precautions and laboratory testing and isolation, and our information from Member States is that, once EU citizens are repatriated, quarantine measures will be taken. We have joined forces with as many other entities and bodies as possible, and Member States have assured us through the CDC that their laboratories are ready. Finally, I wanted to say that, under the Union Civil Protection Mechanism, further emergency assistance can be provided if requested, including emergency medical corps, which can be deployed both inside and outside the European Union. So I will stop here. I just want to be absolutely emphatic that we are going to continue to monitor this very closely. We are monitoring it on a daily basis – responsibly, without creating panic, but also being aware that we have a complex evolving situation that we need to be aware of, and I will be available to inform the Parliament at any point in time of any developments.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for today’s exchange of views on this topic, which is of crucial importance for the health of EU citizens at home and abroad. The Croatian Presidency will do its part, in close cooperation with the EU bodies responsible for health and other Member States, to ensure continued monitoring of the development of the situation in China, but also in other south-eastern Asian countries and indeed in the European Union, so that necessary measures can be taken if the situation gets worse. At this stage, we do not consider that the situation in Europe constitutes a crisis. However, to make sure, we are ready for any developments, and we believe it is prudent to enable maximum information sharing among the European partners as well as to our citizens. The activation of the Integrated Political Crisis Response mechanism offers a practical tool to do that. Furthermore, we underline the important work done by the Health Security Committee and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control. I assure you that we very closely follow the development of this potentially very serious disease outbreak. There are established EU structures for handling serious health threats – I think in particular of the Health Security Committee and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, which both do an excellent job. For the time being, there is, in our view, no reason to assume that those structures, in combination with increased vigilance from national authorities, would not suffice for protecting public health in the European Union. The Presidency will keep the situation under close review and will keep you actively informed.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: Writing. – The activation of the European Civil Protection Mechanism was the first response of the EU institutions to help Member States combat the spread of the new coronavirus from China. Through this mechanism, the EU can provide assistance to EU citizens in need anywhere in the world. For example, two aircraft have already been provided to repatriate EU citizens from the Wuhan region. This is only the beginning, given the epidemic spread of the dangerous coronavirus, member states' requests for assistance will undoubtedly increase. Coordination, material assistance and, in particular, appropriate communication and exchange of information must continue to be of the highest quality, as these procedures are EU added value. The situation cannot be underestimated, but at the same time we must do everything we can to prevent panic following the spread of the coronavirus to Europe, which could damage our economy and society perhaps more than the virus itself. The protection of human health must come first and all the efforts of the EU institutions must be subordinated to this. Our competent authorities must cooperate with the World Health Organisation, as well as with China, the US, Israel, Russia and others, on the rapid development of the vaccine, but cooperation must also be encouraged in the production and distribution of appropriate antivirals and in the repatriation of citizens. With working together and following the procedures laid down, it could be possible to protect our population from much worse health and social consequences.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (2019/3015(RSP)). Here, too, I would like to remind you that you can request spontaneous speeches and speeches using the blue card procedure, both in the traditional way and electronically. The instructions can be found at the entrance to the Chamber.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy – Mr President, honourable members, the EU policies on support to indigenous peoples goes back three decades and were last reconfirmed in the May 2017 Council Conclusions on Indigenous Peoples, reaffirming our support for the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. Despite some important gains in the recognition of the rights of indigenous peoples in many countries of the world, in recent years we have also seen a number of setbacks. Most troubling are the high numbers of indigenous leaders and activists killed every year in the defence of their ancestral lands and the environment – at least 40 persons every year. Such tragic crimes underline the high relevance of our policies on support to indigenous peoples and human rights defenders working on land, environment, biodiversity and climate. Specifically on human rights defenders, the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights funds the EU Human Rights Defenders Mechanism, which provided support to more than 30 000 HRDs from 2015 to 2019 and their families through a combination of short-, medium- and long-term initiatives. The EU’s support to land governance and secure access and tenure of land is equally important. While we continue to foster dialogue and promote respect for responsible land governance, the EU is supporting land governance in about 40 countries, with a total budget of 240 million euros. As an example, I mention the EU support to land governance in Colombia, which enabled the collective titling of 280 000 hectares, benefiting some 8 000 indigenous and Afro-Colombian families. Indigenous peoples also feature highly in our enhanced attention to the human rights and environment and climate nexus. During the European Development Days held in June of 2019, the EEAS organised an event dedicated to the strengthening of international solidarity and support to indigenous peoples and environmental human rights defenders. Another event at the EDDS on non-discrimination and the human rights to safe drinking water and sanitation brought testimonies from indigenous experts, along with other experts on other frequently-discriminated groups. Furthermore, the 21st Annual EU NGO Human Rights Forum meeting in December 2019 under the theme of building a fair environmental future had a specific session dedicated to indigenous peoples. Indigenous experts, including the UN Special Rapporteur on the rights of indigenous peoples, along with indigenous youth, had prominent speaking roles, allowing them – together with the invited indigenous participants – to bring forward concerns as possible contributions of indigenous peoples in building a fair environmental future. The afore-mentioned Council Conclusions underscore the crucial importance of further enhancing opportunities for dialogue and consultation with indigenous peoples at all levels of EU cooperation. This includes EU-funded programmes and projects under all aid modalities to secure the full participation of indigenous people; their free, prior, and informed consent in a meaningful and systematic way; and also to inform and underpin EU External Action policy and its implementation worldwide. In follow-up to the Council Conclusions, on 24 and 25 February in Brussels we will host a round table with indigenous peoples’ representatives as well as experts from the four indigenous socio-cultural regions of the world. The specific objectives of the round table will be the identification of the most prevalent and emerging threats to indigenous people’s rights, and to generate recommendations on how to best address indigenous people’s rights through EU policy and action. Mr President, please allow me now to mention briefly some examples of support that we provide in the context of indigenous peoples’ languages. In Namibia, the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights contributed to the revitalisation of endangered indigenous languages. In the Chittagong Hill Tracts of Bangladesh, we have also helped develop a multilingual mother-tongue education programme in seven different tribal languages as part of the 500 million the EU invests annually in education programmes in around 60 countries across the world. Such programmes and projects can be seen as the EU’s contribution to the success of the International Decade of Indigenous Languages 2020-2029, which was proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly in December of last year. Let me assure you and the honourable Members of the EU’s strong commitment to the rights of indigenous peoples as part of our human rights policies. As such, we remain firmly committed to their promotion and respect through all aspects of EU external policies, cooperation and trade, as well as through political dialogues with third countries in regional and multilateral lateral fora and by giving financial support. Honourable Members, Mr President, thank you for your attention, and I look forward to our discussion tonight.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, indigenous communities are present in about 90 countries on five continents and keep alive more than 5,000 cultures and a large part of the 7,000 existing languages. More than 80% of the world's biodiversity is in your care, as well as the vast majority of forests. Although there are only 370 million people who identify as members of indigenous peoples, they are responsible for almost a quarter of the planet, and are therefore the first to suffer the effects of extreme climate change and the struggle for resources. From Asia to the Amazon, from the Arctic to Oceania, indigenous communities fight to defend their heritage and history, and when they do, they are constantly victims of attacks, occupation, militarization of territories, intimidation, violence and torture that so often lead to death – actions dictated by the voracious of extractive industries, deforestation, mining, agribusiness, with total impunity and so often by the action of the States themselves. At a recent meeting of the indigenous peoples of the Amazon, Chief Raoni Metuktire, a finalist for the Sakharov Prize, said that in Brazil, threats to these communities and environmentalists have been dramatically escalated. The policies advocated by the Bolsonaro government for indigenous territories represent genocide, ethnocide and ecocidium, and I underline these words. Indigenous peoples are one of the most unprotected peoples in the world. They make up only 5% of the population, but represent 15% of people living in poverty. We have heard many speeches, we have seen many conversations, but we need to move from political recognition to action. And so I ask you, Commissioner, knowing that many of these problems spart from the struggle for the exploitation of land and resources: how do you view the accountability of predatory European companies and how do you see the implementation of the European mechanism for banning the import of raw products and materials taken from indigenous territories without authorisation and in violation of the right to consultation?

name: Stéphane BIJOUX
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, here in our European Parliament we work for 500 million people. But all over the world, there are also 500 million women and men who are the last ambassadors of the ancestral strength of indigenous peoples; and among them are Europeans: the Kanaks of New Caledonia, the Maohi of Polynesia; the Bushiningé and all the others on the rivers of Guyana and the Inuit of Greenland. So, you know when they see their icebergs melting at the North Pole, how can we not understand that there is an absolute urgency? When, in their Amazon rainforest, their rivers are poisoned with mercury by illegal gold miners: they must be protected. When on their islands in the Pacific, they see ocean levels rising, the European Green Pact must intervene. In the face of climate change, we are looking for solutions. Well, Aboriginal people have solutions, they are ancestral know-how. Protecting them there also means saving lives here.

name: Anna CAVAZZINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Paulo Paulino, Firmino and Raimundo Guajajara, Chief Emrya Wajãpi, Chief Francisco de Souza Pereira: all of them, murdered. They had one thing in common: they were Brazilian indigenous leaders and defended their land, their people and the forest.  Invasions of indigenous lands in Brazil have increased 150% since Bolsonaro’s election in October 2018. The number of murders of indigenous leaders in the Brazilian Amazon has hit its highest level in two decades. And this is, since his first day in office Bolsonaro has pushed to roll back protections for indigenous lands and pave the way for logging, mining and agricultural interests. The situation in Brazil is really an emergency.  I call on the Brazilian Government to stop the attacks on indigenous people and their land. I call on European companies to make sure that their business in Brazil is not driving these crimes and I call on the Commission not to conclude this Mercosur agreement, which will increase the pressure on indigenous land.

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the There is no doubt that the indigenous peoples are victims. They have been inflicted great suffering. Their land was robbed of them, their traditions were disregarded, their culture was destroyed. The indigenous peoples themselves were mistreated and killed. But that could also be the future of Europe. If it is not racist to defend people, cultures and traditions in other parts of the world, then it cannot be racist to defend the inhabitants, the culture and the traditions of Europe. Integrating qualified immigrants is not the same as welcoming all cultures and millions of immigrants indiscriminately and naively. Nor should we Europeans be forced by the EU's self-sufficient and democratically unlegitimised resettlement policy to adapt our culture and our values to any strangers. The EU must stop accepting illegal migration as inevitable and stop criticising countries that protect their borders. That's rule of law, that's not hate speech. Europe's people, cultures and traditions deserve as much protection and respect as those of indigenous peoples.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, from America to Asia, indigenous and indigenous peoples face the same threats.  A year ago, in a similar debate, we demanded that trade agreements be not signed that would allow or encourage the exposure of indigenous lands and the violation of their rights. And what has the European Union done all this time? For, for example, to accelerate trade negotiations with Mercosur, which include a country like Brazil, with a far-right government, which harasses indigenous peoples to expolite their lands.  80% of the planet's biodiversity, crucial to any climate change strategy, is in indigenous territories. Let's stop hypocrisy, ladies and gentlemen. The rights of indigenous peoples must be above corporate power, the power of European multinationals.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: – Mr President, despite being systematically discriminated against or oppressed by colonial states, indigenous peoples are vital to the preservation of our ecological balance, because for them their ecosystems are an intrinsic part of their identity. Over the past thirty years, their international recognition has improved, particularly with the 2017 United Nations Declaration, but every year thousands of them continue to be criminalized for defending their right to self-government and land.  Only they can protect the nature of the neocolonial mindset of some rulers and the neoliberal mentality of some multinationals. We must also support them from Europe, but not only with good words. The European Union has an obligation to review all its free trade agreements to ensure that neither the territory nor the resources of indigenous peoples are used without their consent. As the Resolution says, indigenous peoples have the right to self-determination. It is our duty to respect and protect him.

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: – Mr President, this is one of those debates that we are postponing because there is never a hot topic on the agenda of the week, as were the Brazilian fires last summer. I believe that, precisely as Mrs Santos said, having had in the Sakharov Prize some candidates of indigenous peoples has at least raised the issue.  Indigenous peoples have to be treated fairly ⸺ as all colleagues have said⸺ but they also have to be treated with strategic intelligence. Traditional paternalistic Eurocentrism must be abandoned and indigenous peoples incorporated into contemporary debates and global decision-making, for example on climate change. Combining the ancestral wisdoms of indigenous cultures with the technological development of developed countries is an advantage, it is an asset that we have to explore. And we need to start talking far beyond North-South cooperation ⸺sover also beyond South-South cooperation⸺ and start talking about South-North cooperation. And there are some radiant examples of how, from countries like Kenya, a Nobel laureate was able, with traditional systems and using the women's workforce, to plant fifty million trees.  Colleagues have said this: indigenous peoples must be protected. But they must also be defended for their added value, because of the capital gains they represent in the global economic and social order.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: – Mr President, we are talking about indigenous peoples and we are talking about more than 5,000 indigenous peoples in 90 different countries. Of all that population, 185 million are women.  It has been said that indigenous peoples have defended over the centuries their home, their surroundings; and defending their home have defended everyone's house. Today we know that many endangered species are preserved because they have defended biodiversity, their environment, sometimes with their lives. We must protect them, we must respect them and we must make a special defence, Commissioner, of women.  Twenty years ago Vandana Shiva was already telling us: in most cultures, women have been the guardians of biodiversity. They produce, reproduce, consume and conserve biodiversity in the practice of agriculture. Let us protect them, protect them especially, because respecting their lives guarantee the lives of all of us.

name: Marie TOUSSAINT
text: Mr President, ecocides are gaining ground. In Australia, Aboriginal people have seen their lands ravaged by mega-fires whose magnitude is closely linked to global warming. Their alerts have not been heard and their knowledge, including those held about nature, has been ignored and denied. For too long, we have despised the Aboriginal knowledge of women and men who know how to respect and protect the living. It's time to respect their rights. Indigenous peoples have knowledge and know-how from afar. These peoples have not forgotten that we are all part of the living. The relationship they have with nature should inspire us more. Let us have the wisdom to become modest again, to finally recognize the rights of nature, to put an end to the reckless modes of production and consumption that are destroying the planet. The time for ecology has come: let us protect the future by reconciling humans and nature, social justice and environmental justice, the rights of indigenous peoples and universalism.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, systematic and institutional discrimination against indigenous people is alive and well, and it’s not confined to one continent or one field, it’s across the board: health, employment, social protection, on top of historic injustices that they have faced from dispossession of their lands, territories and resources. So when we look at the challenges, whether it’s the Amazon rainforest lost to flames or the catastrophe of the fires in Australia, indigenous people offer the world innovative solutions, solving some of the biggest challenges. According to the United Nations, the world has an estimated 370 million indigenous people. They make up about one third of the world’s 900 million people in rural areas who are classified as extremely poor. Yet indigenous voices continue to be marginalised. In the mainstream media and in politics, their struggle for equal rights remains unheard. Indigenous women, in particular, suffer from multiple discrimination, both as women and based on their indigenous status. The Commission really needs to ensure that these rights are upheld and that they have a seat at the decision-making table.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Madam President, yes, this is a very serious subject. This is indeed a threat and a continuing threat to the rights of hundreds of millions of people on this planet. People, natives who actually own their own land, have their own land and are often deceived by various large companies that try to profit on their land, to extract various mineral resources, and thus to toxicate this land. So here, indeed, not only climate change and not only poverty, but also such serious things as endangering their health through soil toxication. But also, of course, threatening women's rights. But also the persecution itself and the killing of activists who fight for their rights. That is why we, as the European Union, must stand up and do everything we can to include the rights of these indigenous peoples worldwide in our international cooperation treaties with other third countries. We have to try to make it the standard. After all, we are interested in the law of law, about the rule of law, about human rights. That is what we need to demonstrate in this area.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, phrases such as "more and more the Indian is a human being equal to us", or "dream of a Bolivia free of indigenous satanic rituals", by Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil and of Jeanine Áñez in Bolivia, are representative of the way capitalism views indigenous peoples, the native populations of invaded, occupied and exploited territories from north to south in America , and from the Pacific Islands to Australia. The back of centuries of occupation is death and expropriation. These peoples continue, in general, to be regarded as sub-human, a hindrance to the territorial and cultural colonization of capitalist, in their path of appropriating and monetizing natural resources, even if for this it has to continuously trample national legislation, UN resolutions and thousands of human lives. The European Union, with its support for coups d'état or free trade agreements, is complicit in the murders, the occupation of territorial reserves, the loss of cultural heritage and the daily violation of the rights of indigenous peoples.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today it is not only ecosystems, animals and plants that are at risk of extinction, but also peoples, cultures and civilisations. Indigenous or tribal peoples make up only just over 4 % of the world's population, but they represent more than 90 % of the cultural diversity of our planet.  Victims of history, European colonial expansion, the technical, economic and military supremacy of Western civilisation, the natives have remained in a position of subordination, have lost almost all their territories and are reduced to living on the fringes of a society alien to them, deprived of their right to self-determination, their land and their own resources. These populations are now succubi of renewed economic and commercial interests, exploited as cheap labour, forced to leave their land when resources or wealth are discovered and, again, main victims of the effects of deforestation and climate change, from the melting of glaciers to global warming itself. Ladies and gentlemen, more and better must be done to protect the guardians of the earth from ancient threats and new ones, but above all, we must intensify the dialogue with these populations, who, with their deep knowledge of the environment in which they live, can and must play a key role in the effort against climate change.

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their interventions and their suggestions. Of course, we can always do more and we can always do better. And let me reiterate the high importance that the EU attaches to reversing the negative trends that we are currently seeing as regards the enjoyment of human rights by indigenous people. So support for indigenous people’s rights will remain high on our agenda. With regard to the issue raised by Ms Santos, business, yes, may indeed have impacts on the rights of indigenous people, and the Commission is ready to consider the issue in the ongoing reflections on the policy related to responsible business conduct. So thank you for your comments. I will make some remarks now on the EU approach on human rights in Brazil within the future EU-Mercosur Agreement. The EU follows closely the situation of human rights in Brazil, particularly human rights defenders, indigenous peoples and all those working to protect land, environment, biodiversity and climate. Indigenous peoples feature prominently also in our comprehensive and sustained contact and cooperation with Brazil, for instance by regular visits by the EU delegation in Brasília, to different regions and indigenous communities, regular visits by the EU Special Representative for Human Rights as well. The last edition of the EU-Brazil dialogue on human rights was on 9 October 2019, and it included a focus on indigenous peoples, human rights defenders, labour standards, businesses and human rights, and children’s and women’s rights, which already also were mentioned here tonight. And in particular we voiced our concern on the situation of indigenous peoples and human rights defenders. Our offer of cooperation was positively appreciated by the Brazilians, and as a positive follow-up to this dialogue, Brazil invited the EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Mr Gilmore, to visit the country during 2020 as a mid-term review of the joint work carried out in these areas between annual dialogues. The EU-Mercosur Association Agreement would serve as a valuable tool to further promote the protection of human rights and to address environmental issues in Brazil and the region. It includes provisions on human rights, indigenous peoples and cooperation on sustainable development. It will provide for upgraded mechanisms for enhanced political dialogue and cooperation between the two sides of these issues. These include specific mechanisms for EU-Mercosur dialogue and exchanges between parties, including at the level of parliaments and civil societies of both regions. In the trade part, a trade and sustainable development chapter provides for binding commitment to the effective implementation of the multilateral environmental agreements – including the Paris Agreement – ratified by each of the parties. These will bring reinforced commitments and tools for regular dialogue with our partners.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – The UN General Assembly has declared 2019 the International Year of Indigenous Languages. As co-chair of the EP Minority Working Group, I was personally involved in the preparation of this thematic year, which aimed to promote and protect indigenous languages and improve the lives of indigenous-speaking communities. The continued disappearance of indigenous languages is a cause for concern in the world. According to a 2016 UN report, 95% of the nearly 6,700 languages currently spoken in the world - the vast majority of which are native languages - are at risk of extinction by the end of the century. Languages are a key component of human rights and fundamental freedoms and are also important for achieving sustainable development, as local knowledge, collective knowledge and experience of indigenous communities are encoded in these languages. Thus, this knowledge, which also contributes to overcoming global environmental challenges, can only be passed on to future generations through these intermediary languages. It is therefore of the utmost importance to protect and promote the use of these languages. Ensuring adequate education is essential for the survival of indigenous languages. The integration of intercultural public policies, indigenous languages and knowledge of history into school programmes should be supported, as this will contribute to preserving, renewing and promoting the culture of indigenous peoples at national and international level.

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Writing. Yes, the rights of indigenous people must be of great concern to us, the European Parliament. When land grabs happen, we must not look away! In times of climate crisis, the greed for profit of a few must not destroy the livelihoods of millennia-old cultures. Ultimately, we can learn a lot from indigenous lifestyles with our environmentally harmful consumption patterns. Now we must not only talk about protecting these people, but we must also act! Let us start to hold companies and governments accountable. Let us create transparency in global supply chains and also oblige them to respect human rights. From manufacturing to the consumer and to the consumer, neither man nor nature should have to suffer.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the revision of the Indian Citizenship Act in 2019 (2020/2519(RSP)).

name: Helena Dalli
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President and honourable Members of this Parliament, the European Union and India enjoy a strong bond rooted in the 2004 strategic partnership. It is based on shared values of democracy, rule of law, respect for human rights, commitment to the rules-based global order, effective multilateralism and sustainable development.  The President of the European Council and the President of the European Commission will host the Prime Minister of India for the 15th EU-India summit on 13 March here in Brussels. We have a rich, frank and open dialogue with India on all issues of common interest, as well as on issues where we might have different perspectives.  The High Representative/Vice-President of the Commission was in India on 16 and 17 January, where he discussed the preparation for the summit. On this occasion, the Minister for External Affairs and Prime Minister Modi reaffirmed their strong interest for a deepened strategic partnership with the European Union.  The issue that you are debating today was also part of the discussions, and the HR/VP enquired about the risk of discrimination among refugees and migrants on religious grounds under the revised legislation. He also drew the attention of his interlocutors to the need to ensure compliance of national legislation with international law. Beyond this point, we believe that it is the role of the Supreme Court of India to assess compliance of the law with the Constitution and we are confident that the ongoing judicial process will contribute to appeasing the tensions and violence witnessed over the past weeks in the country. Thank you for your attention and I look forward to your remarks.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which is India, as the Commissioner rightly said, is an important partner for us, both politically and economically, and we want to improve relations. That is why it is important for us to see what is going on in the country. If we realise that there are difficulties, and even violence and deaths, due to an amended law or other planned legal changes , such as the Registration Act – then that is a point where we are looking more closely. We are doing this in this context, and it is important that we get smart about how to assess the situation here. The law as such does not take anything away from an existing right. There are twelve years as a deadline for all who have lived legally in India, whether they are Muslims or Christians or belong to other faiths or ethnicities. In this case, it is more of a selective privilege, that is, positive discrimination. The question then arises as to whether there is any real criticism in this context. The criticism that I am sure we can make is that, in the context of the debate on this law, the law on the registration of citizens is also being revised. There are fears that many citizens will not be able to prove that they actually have a right to be in India. I believe that clarity must be provided here. I am glad that we are now also waiting until we have the opportunity to talk to government representatives here in two weeks' time or at the next opportunity. Then we should make our judgment, even in the light of what the supreme court says. Quick shots are wrong with such important partners, but I am prepared to criticise where it is appropriate.

name: John HOWARTH
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I find and many of the people I represent find the Indian Citizenship Act amendments alarming. This cannot be dressed up. This is a highly discriminatory piece of legislation which targets a specific religion. Muslims are singled out and the threat that this legislation represents to the secular nature of India should be clear, and it’s all very well asking the Indian Government what’s actually going on, what they think, but I don’t believe this is necessarily a government they can trust. I mean, they’re going to say that it’s okay, but the reality appears to me to be somewhat different, and the reports of violence that we hear from India are on the increase. I think a message needs to be sent to the Indian Government from the European Union – because this is a government of Hindu nationalism, a populist government out of the same mold that we have seen elsewhere in the world. The message needs to be very clear: whether it’s Kashmir or the rights of citizens, respect for human rights is an essential element of the arrangements that this Union makes with other partners, and without that respect for human rights, our relationship as the European Union with India will come under serious threat.

name: Dinesh DHAMIJA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, India takes in persecuted refugees from Afghanistan, Pakistan and Bangladesh – and they’re the bad guys? No, they’re the good guys. They’ve taken in the refugees. This motion does not censure any of those three Muslim countries for having created this refugee crisis. The UN Minorities Declaration of 1992 states that minorities can be classified as national, ethnic, religious, linguistic or cultural. This act, the CAA, is just focused on persecuted religious minorities seeking refuge in India. Thus, Muslims coming from those three Muslim countries cannot be considered minorities. Muslims do have a right to become Indian citizens by the 1955 act, of course. The CAA allows Christians, Hindus, Buddhists, Jains and Parsis and Sikhs to become citizens after six years of living in India. These are persecuted religious minorities.  There are many things wrong with our motion today, but I’ll just give you four: Rohingyas, Tamils, police violence and the National Register of Citizens. Rohingyas are a religious Muslim minority leaving Myanmar for Bangladesh. When they come from Bangladesh to India they become economic migrants because they’re coming from a majority Muslim state. Violence and brutality of the police: let me inform you that 57 policemen had bullet wounds in a demonstration in Lucknow. Tamils are an ethnic minority, not a religious minority. The National Register of Citizens is not even mentioned in the CAA. Are we saying that India, or any other country for that matter, is not allowed to document the people living inside its boundaries?  The CAA is in front of the Supreme Court and thus should be considered sub judice. The real reason for this motion has come before us: the India-EU summit. Should we not be talking to the Indians rather than criticising them and playing neo—colonial politics. We must have a debate but we must also have a summit.

name: Scott AINSLIE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I say to my colleagues that I am utterly heartbroken by the appalling decision that we have taken today to postpone the cross-party resolution on India’s Islamophobic Citizenship Act – a resolution to which all the main groups had committed and the EPP has co-signed, but today they have chosen to postpone the vote yet again. Faced with the pressure of India’s diplomatic lobby, the EU have crumbled, capitulated, prioritising yet another trade summit with India over our commitment to protecting human rights. We have refused to take a stand on this Islamophobic policy which could drive 200 million Muslims – nearly half the EU’s population – toward statelessness, incarceration or deportation. In the state of Assam, 1.9 million citizens have already felt the curse of this nationalistic move by Modi. It’s shameful. Now, many words were said in this Chamber today and from your seat to say that the only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good people to do nothing. Today, colleagues, we are doing nothing – to protect the rights of Muslims. Today’s persecuted peoples. This will be the very last time I address Parliament, but I want to leave you with this simple plea: do not allow the Indian Government to use its diplomatic and political might to buy itself impunity. Stay strong and principled and fight against human rights violations and injustices, speak truth to power and hold, the authoritarians to account, but you must act. Words are not enough.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Madam President, India is a democracy, the largest democracy in the world if one takes into account its population. His government and prime minister were elected and re-elected. Commissioner, you have made some soothing remarks: yes, we must have a partnership with India; and yes, above all, this law is currently in the middle of a democratic process. India has a Supreme Court that will judge the validity of this law, and I welcome the fact that the vote on our resolution has been postponed. Indeed, how would this vote have been interpreted in India? Let us imagine that we voted against this law: it was as if the Supreme Court was influenced by the European Union. No, I think that this vote had to be postponed and I think above all that we do not have to vote on this law: it is the sovereignty of the States to choose their nationals. As was said by the EPP speaker, there is actually no change for any part of the population. There is, if I may say so, a fast track that is created for some. In France, there is a fast track on nationality that is created for some nationals who come from countries that shared our story at one time or who speak French. I do not think there is any persecution of anyone in this country and in this law. Finally, how can we not see the hand of Pakistan behind this media campaign against India? Pakistan, which, I repeat, does not respect any international agreement and which we continue to reward the status of GSP. Pakistan, where the Christian minority is under threat. So let's leave it to each state to choose who can have their nationality. India hosts thousands, if not millions, of refugees. In my opinion, it is the countries from which these refugees come from that are to blame, not India, which welcomes them.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for There have just been words about the lobby, the strong lobby, and I think the common sense and respect lobby has won the European Parliament today. Respect for the world's largest democracy (in demographic terms), respect for our very important partner in Asia – an economic partner, as well as political, respect for a very old civilization, respect for a country that has never interfered in our internal affairs of the European Union. When we debated the treaties, there were no comments from New Delhi. I have the impression that a situation in which we will act as teachers, judges or prosecutors is not a good method. This is about partnership and mutual respect. That is what I am calling for.

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, Internet closures, police repression, 170 killed in protests against the Law of Nationality in India. A Law that not only violates the lay nature of the Indian Constitution itself by introducing religion as a criterion for obtaining nationality, but also breaks international human rights commitments, as denounced by the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner.  This Law is not only discriminatory in itself, it is a dangerous resurgence for the rights of all, from the "reactionary international". Prime Minister Modi, in connection with Trump, with Bolsonaro, began his second term with dangerous decisions in the Kashmir conflict by attacking NGOs and closing public liberties.  Europe must stand by the millions of Indian and Indian workers who are going on strikes for their labour rights; women's groups reporting group rapes. This means conditioning the strategic agreement on a substantial change in human rights. Either we are determinedly committed to being an independent political actor who can engage in equal dialogue or Europe itself is at risk.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, although the amendment to the Modi government citizenship law is formulated in terms of apparently reception and protection, in reality this rule is discriminatory and divisive, excluding many religions from the same facilities as others and, together with the establishment of the National Register of Citizens of India, the CAA could in fact lead to a crisis of large-scale statelessness. , not to mention the unnecessary tensions and resentment created in the Muslim community.  Ladies and gentlemen, I wonder whether the purpose of the law was in fact aimed at protecting persecuted minorities, why were other persecuted minorities from neighbouring countries not included? I am thinking, for example, of the Muslim populations of the Rohingya in Myanmar, the Bihari in Bangladesh or even the Ahmadis in Pakistan, and I could go on with a long list.  The Union's external action is based on principles that informed its creation, including the principle of non-discrimination. I deeply regret the decision to postpone today's vote. It is our duty, ladies and gentlemen, as elected representatives, to condemn the actions of the Indian Government and to do everything in our power to reconsider the CAA and perhaps repeal it. India's tradition, history and great cultural wealth do not deserve all this.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, there’s been much disinformation in the run-up to this debate, and even misleading statements in this House by some who have spoken before me, mixing up all sorts of issues. Let’s just stick to the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA). This is an action of positive discrimination aimed at fast—tracking the integration process of refugees from Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh, who have already been in India for many years, recognising the high level of discrimination faced by non-Muslims in those countries. It is not seeking to exclude any of the other groups who do not fall within this category. They can still apply for citizenship and be processed. What really pains me is that I have repeatedly raised the concerns around the persecution of minorities in Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh only for them to fall on deaf ears. Had this house paid a little bit more attention to those gross violations, as we do today to the CAA, India may not have had to take these actions. So I really welcome that the vote has been postponed on the resolution. First, it’s full of factual inaccuracies. Secondly, it is right that we take time to have a proper debate and this House waits until the Supreme Court has deliberated on this. One thing we have to recognise is that India has a very strong civil society and Indians are far more than capable of holding their executive to account without interference from those who know very little about it.

name: Shaffaq MOHAMMED
text: – Madam President, earlier, at the start of this session, we had a very powerful lesson in history, a lesson that’s painful for this Chamber because that’s one of the reasons this House came into being: where one group of people decided another group of people were going to become stateless. I thought this Chamber had learned that lesson and I thought that we were going to be moving on, but what we see now – yes, you can have your meetings and resolutions, but I say to you: I have tried so hard to get this resolution on the table. I postponed the last one. I sat down with all the groups and I thought we had an agreement, but we haven’t. I’m going to be away from here now, I’ll be gone. God forbid, god forbid, if something terrible happens to that new group of people that are going to be made stateless, I can go away with a hand on my heart and say, ‘I did everything possible’, but individuals in here from the top table downwards thought that business and trade interests were more important than human rights. That’s what you’ve done today. Well done. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – You talked about the fact that an important group of citizens will become stateless as a result of this law. Can you tell us the exact figure of citizens who are left without a citizen identity?

name: Shaffaq MOHAMMED
text: blue-card answer. – Apologies for taking my headphones off. If you looked at the motion in ‘H’, this NRC has been enacted in just one state. One state, and 1.9 million people cannot prove that they are Indian citizens. What on earth are you going to do with those people? Because there are already detention camps set up. That’s why I say to you, remember your history: in Nuremberg, that law was also passed, and that was ‘legal’. Just because a law is passed in a Parliament doesn’t mean it is legal. Learn from our history. I am taking his home with me. I am going to hold this in my drawer. God forbid if anything happens, those people that stop this vote today, I’ll be publicly naming them and saying ‘these are the people that have led to this tragedy’.

name: Anna BONFRISCO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Dear High Representative, the European Union has always had close trade relations with India, but it must also recognise its attempt to build and defend the rule of law, despite many, many contradictions.  We owe it to India. India has nothing to do with the countries around it, starting with Pakistan, ideologically and religiously opposed to progress, China, which imposes its authoritarianism on more than a billion people, or Myanmar, with its ethnic cleansing against the Rohingya. Apart from any constitutionality profiles, which we do not have to assess, the European Union's interest must be to avoid any conflict with a country such as India, projected into the future and at the forefront of the world for an education system, that of STEM, a source of well-being for its citizens. India is a country well aware of internal and external threats to its security and is only trying to implement the measures it deems necessary.

name: Phil BENNION
text: – Madam President, I certainly welcome the idea of a Citizenship Amendment Act in offering protection for persecuted groups. Unfortunately, the Act as it stands is seriously flawed. The law does not extend to the protection of Muslims. Now, there are Muslim sects in neighbouring countries that do face discrimination and one of them, the Ahmadiyyas, has already been mentioned. Ultimately, this law discriminates on religious grounds, and is therefore contrary to the whole principle in India of secularism and also its obligations and international human rights law. The danger, if this act is applied alongside the requirements of the National Register of Citizens, is that many Muslims could be deemed stateless if they cannot produce the correct documentation. This is already proving to be an issue in Assam, where – it’s already been stated by Mr Mohammed – 1.9 million people have been excluded from the register on the basis of not having the documents. So, India’s refugee policy needs to be applied to all of those in need, including Muslims, and the Government should ensure that security forces show sufficient restraint towards protesters and are held to account for their excessive use of force.

name: France JAMET
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, no country in the world would admit not to control its borders. India is a sovereign country that has the prerogative to decide who is eligible to apply for citizenship, especially when national cohesion and national and external security are threatened: India is a democracy, as we have all said here, the largest in the world; and a federation in which states are of crucial importance in a significant number of areas. The influx of millions of refugees from Bangladesh, Pakistan and especially Afghanistan is not just a humanitarian fact for India; it is a national challenge to the unity of the already fragile country. India must govern a population of more than one billion 300 million people and does not intend to succumb - as has often been the case in its history - to internal differences, but to take its place in the world as a united nation. That's his strictest right.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I find it frankly disconcerting that for the umpteenth time here in the European Parliament we are talking about other states, questioning the sovereignty that other states have, among other things, by questioning it in a state such as India, which is recognised as a great democracy, especially in Asia. Among other things, on a subject which will include representatives of the European Parliament and Indian leaders who will meet to discuss it between February and March. A theme and a measure that is sub judice and that will be evaluated by the Indian Supreme Court.  However, I ask myself: does it really make sense to question relations between Europe and India on a subject that is clearly indian domestic politics? Above all, I think that the citizens of Europe voted for us to discuss the issues and major problems of Europeans, not Indians or other states. I will close with one thing: the text includes attacks on the government, it talks about closing internet access and many other things, so it is clear that we as a group will be against it.

name: Helena Dalli
