text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I have taken due note of the various opinions expressed by the honourable Members today. The EU values its partnership with India – may I reiterate this. It’s a respected democracy, the largest in the world and the oldest in Asia, and we look forward to pursuing and intensifying our dialogue with India at the forthcoming summit on the whole range of issues of common interest, including our mutual commitment to democracy, the rule of law and human rights. I thank you and good night.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I have received six motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place during the second part-session in March. Written declarations (Article 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In December 2019, a law was adopted in India granting citizenship to migrants who arrived in the country from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan before 2015, provided they are not Muslims. Such a law cannot be called other than discrimination. There is no explanation to justify discriminating against or excluding people on the basis of or lack of religion. There is no excuse for discrimination on the basis of any characteristic – gender, age, fitness level, ethnicorigin, sexual orientation or any other reason.  Two days ago, Holocaust survivor Marian Turski, speaking on the 75th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, said: "Do not be indifferent when any minority is discriminated against, because the essence of democracy is that the majority governs, but democracy is that minority rights must be protected at the same time." People who have survived hell as a result of exclusion and hatred must be listened to.  The European Union and India have good relations and regularly engage in dialogue. It is important that, in this dialogue, we pay close attention to the fact that a law that excludes that a law that discriminates is always wrong ends. It is also important that we pay attention to the value of a secular state, a state in which churches and religious associations are separated from public authority.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. – The nationality law passed by the Indian Parliament in December 2019 has led to violence on the streets. We need to take a close look at what is happening, seek clarification from the authorities and await the decision of the Supreme Court of India. In 15 days, government representatives and India's prime minister will come to Brussels and that will be an opportunity to seek clarification. Since independence in 1947, India has undertaken admirable development, consolidating itself as a democratic benchmark in the region and even as a paladin of tolerance and diversity. One regulation that openly discriminates against Muslims and challenges their neighbouring countries would create a problem with their Muslim minority. Such policies risk widening the gap between Muslims and Hindus and making it difficult for Muslims to enter the country would be to give them a sense of second-rate citizens. If confirmed, a reason for radicalization would be created, in a country where there have so far been no major problems with jihadist terrorism. I am confident that the Government will clarify the situation and rectify what it needs to rectify before violence on the streets worsens.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the Statement by the Council and the Commission on the urgent humanitarian situation on the Greek islands, in particular the situation of children, for action to protect, relocate and reunite families (2020/2520(RSP)).

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like first of all to thank you for this timely debate. As you know, the Croatian Presidency is particularly sensitive to the situation in the eastern Mediterranean, which has a direct impact on the flow of migrants in the whole of south-eastern Europe and even further. We are closely monitoring the events on the migration routes and we will continue to do so throughout our Presidency. The situation on the Greek islands is currently very difficult. In 2019, more than 60 000 migrants arrived in Greece by sea, compared to 32 000 recorded in 2018. This represents an increase of 87% – far greater than the 9% percent increase recorded in 2017 and 2018. The number of people present on the Aegean islands increased significantly, reaching a peak of over 40 000 migrants. It is the first time since the implementation of the EU-Turkey statement that we have reached such a high number. Among them, there are several thousand children and unaccompanied minors who were accommodated in facilities which are not adapted to their needs. According to the UNHCR, around 40% of the 20 000 migrants in and around the Moria Camp are under 18 and nearly half of those are under 12 years old. Due to the high number of arrivals, the situation on the islands continues to deteriorate. The humanitarian situation requires our close follow-up, and we will continue supporting the efforts of Greece to relieve the situation. The Greek government is undertaking concrete actions to improve the situation, inter alia by increasing the number of transfers to the mainland. In 2019, more than 35 000 migrants have been transferred but, unfortunately, this has not decreased the pressure on the islands. Further actions are needed. The Greek Government has also announced a new scheme to protect unaccompanied minors reaching the country. I understand that the No Child Alone plan was designed to protect unaccompanied children from exploitation and criminality and includes commitments to swiftly create new structures to provide long-term accommodation for thousands of children. These new structures will provide housing, education, food and medical support. The plan also foresees the necessary legal services to allow accompanied minors to reunite with relatives in other Member States. We also take note of government measures to speed up and streamline asylum procedures and manage flows to Greece by improving border surveillance. Some of these measures are part of the new asylum legislation which recently entered into force in Greece. It will be important to implement the new provisions as fast as possible, including regarding the return procedures. The return rate so far has been a very low, for far too long. Returns are instrumental in keeping the numbers down on the islands and managing the flows. The plan of the Greek Government includes a target of returning 10 000 migrants by the end of 2020. This is ambitious, but it can be done, with the appropriate procedures in place and assistance from IOM, Frontex and EU Member States and through cooperation with third countries. Effective returns also require the cooperation of Turkey. In this respect, it is vital that both parties apply in good-faith all the provisions and operating procedures agreed as a result of the EU-Turkey statement. On a broader note, I would like to use the opportunity of this debate to reiterate that the Croatian Presidency intends to continue its focus on implementation with regard to the comprehensive approach to migration. We will do our part to ensure coherent action at EU level in terms of more effective control of the EU external borders, increased external actions and address internal aspects. I would like to stress that the humanitarian situation on the Greek islands is a cause of great concern. We have to work together to relieve the humanitarian situation. And let me also express here our appreciation for the work of all humanitarian partners. I will let the Commission further elaborate on the assistance and advice the EU provides to the Greek Government on this issue.

name: Ylva Johansson
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, as we are standing here, sitting here, speaking, waiting for our turn, more than 40 000 migrants are stuck in so—called hot spots on the Greek islands.  Most of them are living under conditions that are totally unacceptable. Many of them are children. I can only imagine being a mother in these hot spots, with children, being responsible for children, and living in a tent when it’s cold, there’s not enough food, with terrible conditions in many aspects, and being responsible for your own children and not being able to actually take responsibility as a mother. Or being a mother in a totally other country knowing that your teenager, your teenage boy, is alone there as unaccompanied minor.  These conditions are not acceptable, this we can’t stand having in the European Union in 2020. I am probably not the only one who keeps awake at night thinking about these people and the conditions they are living under. But, of course, nobody will be helped by me being awake at night. I’m the Commissioner and I am of course responsible for doing things, and you who are here tonight will probably ask me, quite rightly, what is the Commission doing and what more can we do? The Commission is supporting the Greek authorities with finding shelter for unaccompanied minors on the mainland. We will continue to support Greece and relocate people from the islands to new centres – new centres that will meet the minimum European standards for humanitarian intervention. We support the Greek authorities with our European funds. To mention just a few: EUR 50 million from the asylum migration and integration fund that supports up to 2 000 places in shelter for unaccompanied minors on the mainland; EUR 4.2 million for the IOM to create additional safe zones for unaccompanied minors on all the Greek islands; funds for a specific facility for vulnerable applicants called Kara Tepe on Lesbos; specific facilities also exist on Kos and Leros. We will continue to support Greece with our funds. I welcome the appointment that the Greek Government has done to appoint a national coordinator for unaccompanied minors. I think that the Greek Government shows the right emphasis on this very difficult situation, and I welcome that the Greek Government are committed to improve the living conditions for migrants, bringing them to new centres, reforming the asylum system and also starting returning those that are not eligible for international protection. We also think that additional incentives for the employment of doctors in the reception centres and identification centres is important. It is of great urgency to release unaccompanied minors from protective custody and transfer them to safe zones – zones that are suitable for long—term accommodation. Is this enough? Apparently not. We need to do more. Yesterday I met with the newly—appointed Greek Migration Minister, Notis Mitarakis. We discussed measures as to how we can help Greece more and what also the Greek Government and the Greek authorities are planning. Yesterday also, the European Asylum Support Office signed an agreement with Greece to double the staff in Greece from EASO.  The Commission will continue to show solidarity with Greece. This includes financial support of over EUR 2.2 billion. But the Commission alone cannot do everything. We also need the support from the Member States. We are lacking a common European asylum and migration system. In lack of that, we need voluntary support from other Member States. Greece has asked for the relocation of unaccompanied minors and I strongly support this. I support all solidarity efforts between Member States, especially when it comes to children. I call on Member States to continue to help Greece, to continue voluntary relocations and we, the Commission, will do the financial support. We will continue to work closely with the Greek authorities to help facilitate all voluntary solidarity efforts by other Member States.  I call on Member States to speed up the necessary procedures to reunify children with their families as soon as possible. Honourable Members, we talk about migration policy and the migration situation in Europe. It’s clear that even though we can see an increase of migrants arriving in Greece and especially at the Greek islands the overall situation is not a crisis. We have seen fewer irregular arrivals in the European Union than for many years. We are not in crisis; we do not have a migration crisis in Europe. But there are at least 40 000 individuals on the Greek islands and they are in crisis.  We need to support them and the most effective thing that we must do is to find a common solution that can unite Member States and Parliament in a new pact for migration and asylum. Every week, every month that we are not able to find this new common policy means these people paying too high a price.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Commissioner, once again we see a failure in the effective management of migration. Desperate people arrive daily in Greece from Turkey, through traffickers, and the situation is now dramatic. The islands are destroyed and the hinterland is unable to hold such a large crowd. Unaccompanied minors exceeded 5,000, and the country's capacity today is not enough to cover half of them.  The Greek Government requested assistance from the Member States, and only France, Portugal, Bulgaria and the Czech Republic responded positively. For family reunifications there is a great problem due to excessive requirements but also contradictory laws invoked by the Member States. In Greece we are experiencing a harsh humanitarian crisis and we feel we are alone. Only five countries have the European family? How do we demonstrate practical solidarity when, even in the drama of underage children, they turn their backs? The Greek government is implementing a new migration policy and, especially for children, the Prime Minister announced a "no child only" initiative aimed at severely punishing traffickers and completing 4,000 shelters for unaccompanied minors. But it is not possible to manage it without help. Greeks' distrust of Europe's values is growing, and not unfairly.  Turkey continues its illegal policy against us by exploiting human souls, and the vast majority of Member States do not care. This is not how the situation can go on. We're sounding the alarm. Migration is already seriously shaking the foundations of the European Union. You know that delays in new actions are intensifying tension. I will not tire of saying this: we must all, without exceptions, take responsibility now. Greece does not ask for privileges. She's exercising her rights. Colleagues, today we said goodbye with regret to the United Kingdom and we hope that no one else will follow. But without justice, in the years to come we risk lamenting consequences of mistakes and omissions. We've achieved too much. Failure is not worth it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the Commissioner was very robust in stating how unacceptable these conditions are, because they exist within the European Union. We have many refugee hotspots around the world, but this is the problem: they exist within the European Union, and they are afflicting – as we heard from the last speaker – Greece in particular. She and the Commissioner explained what the elephant in the room was: Member State coordination is lacking.  We are asking today for the Commission to act: this, for my group, is really the most important thing. I’ve been to the islands many times – other speakers will speak of this – and we need action, and the Commissioner prefaced this in the details that she gave. So, for my group, that is not to talk again about all the chronic and severe problems of under—staffing in the hotspots – the risks for children under Dublin, and so on – but to say that we need to act on long—term reception capacities on the mainland in the overcrowded hotspots, to deploy additional expert staff, and to provide crucial legal information to end the regime of geographical restrictions. So we ask the Commission to do everything it can, but of course the Member States must do more: this is really the elephant at the room. If we don’t have this combined comprehensive approach, we will continue to have these – as the Commissioner said – unacceptable conditions within the European Union.  Commissioner, this is my last speech after 20 years and six months (remember the six months!), and for much of that time I have spoken about these issues: humanitarian issues and issues of asylum. I’ve been to the Greek islands many times, and I know that these issues affect the European Union disproportionately for what they are, because they define the values of the European Union. So I really urge colleagues to do everything they can to ensure that we solve this problem, because it affects the very values of the European Union: we send a message to the world about what kind of European Union we are. I wish you all the best of luck to deal with this issue as comprehensively as possible in the coming months.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, thank you very much for being here. You have been in office for a short time, and from what you have told us, you know the fundamental elements of those centers that have become hell. But it's not in 2020 that Moria, or whatever might be in Samos or Chios, is hell. It's been like this since 2015, since 2016, and we're still the same or worse.  Moria is a factory of traumatic stress, post-traumatic stress, moral suffering. And we can't allow it. You're talking about how we're going to help get new centers, when are they going to be? You're talking about the EASO staff being doubled. I've been to the island of Lesbos twice. I've never been able to see anyone from EASO. We don't know how much is twice as much as zero.  Understand me, our group is a responsible group. We want to help have a new migration and asylum pact. We're ready for commitments. But if you don't get those poor people off the Greek islands, if you don't help Greece, you're not going to make it. Because nobody's going to trust us to be serious. And those kids and those women and those old people can't wait, they can't wait any longer. So when are we going to have these new reception centres, Commissioner?

name: Erik MARQUARDT
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you, Mrs Johansson, for your words, for your really strong words and efforts. I myself have been to Lesbos many times, and now people send me pictures and messages every day. When I see the pictures, I actually see mainly suffering, I see coldness, I see lack of perspective and increasingly also violence. And it makes me sad that this is not the first winter, but the fourth winter in which people have to spend the winter there in unheated tents. I must also say that when people suffer, politics must act. It is good that we are talking here, but in order to act at last, perhaps we do not even need a new Commission asylum pact, but actually only the will of the Member States to respect human dignity and the rule of law to work for it. Without this will, if it does not become visible now, the Commission's new asylum pact is also doomed to failure. We can and will also argue here about asylum policy, we will have different opinions and discuss it. But if our Member States do not even save children who hibernate in the mud, how are we supposed to save European asylum policy? I think that, given the conditions on the Greek islands, it would be right for at least individual Member States to go ahead and send a signal and first evacuate the children from the Greek islands. Because I think that for years we have simply failed for too long because of our own demands. We shut ourselves off and believe that we will be better off. But Europe is no better off if we turn a blind eye to the fact that people are doing badly. This policy not only degrades the people at Europe's external borders, but also degrades Europe. And I think we can actually be more successful than that.

name: Annalisa TARDINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, last November we discussed hot spots in Greece in Strasbourg, and today we are still here with the same words, but no fact.  Greece saw the arrival of more than 70,000 migrants in 2019 and, according to the latest statistics, about 30,000 migrants or refugees are currently in Greece. We are facing a real humanitarian crisis that requires concrete and immediate action. And what concrete and immediate actions is the EU taking, as well as being blackmailed by Erdogan? Billions of euros from our taxpayers that we could have used more profitably. And I do not think that the approach of the new Commission is so different. There is talk of a new, decisive plan for migration and asylum, but, from what we have heard, the situation in Greece will remain so. I also wonder how this plan will help to improve the situation in Italy, which for years has been dealing with the emergency on its own, which has been courageously blocked only by our government, even at the cost of a trial. Unfortunately, in no way, until you go to the root of the problem, if you ever do.

name: Emmanouil FRAGKOS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, listening to the positions of some MEPs, even Greeks, one thinks that they are here representing the citizens of Pakistan, Syria, Afghanistan and other third countries who are in Greece illegally. But because the Greek Solution and Kyriakos Velopoulos are fighting every day against this settlement that is happening in Greece, I want to talk about the situation that Greeks are experiencing on the Greek islands, which no one talks about. The European Union is unaware that the Greeks are close to becoming a minority in Greece, and that the locals, not only on the islands but also throughout the country, stand helpless and look at their property, their families and the places in which they grew up being destroyed and threatened by illegal immigration. Will the European Union do something about this crisis or will it always thank Greece for standing in solidarity with its own invaders? Since we have come to the point of discussing the reunification of the families of illegal immigrants, I want to say one more thing: In recent years, due to the economic crisis, almost half a million young Greeks of my generation, who had finished a University, like me, but could not find work in Greece, have left my country and their families. These people now meet their parents and relatives for only a few days a year. With this family reunification, then, the European Union must deal, because everything else goes beyond the tolerance of the Greeks.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure.))

name: Damian BOESELAGER
text: blue-card question. – I have a very simple question for you, and that is this: are you willing to uphold the right to asylum and the right to have an interview to determine the asylum status?

name: Emmanouil FRAGKOS
text: answer a question with a blue card. First of all, I speak on behalf of my group. I happen to come from one of those islands we're talking about today. I grew up in Chios and I've seen all the evolution of the island over the years and that's why I speak a little more strongly. The situation is tragic and needs to change now. All these illegal immigrants must be repatriated immediately.

name: Konstantinos ARVANITIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, what you have heard before is not Greece. It's a far-right concept. We know a picture is a thousand words. Commissioner, this is the situation in Moria today. Two days ago he went there, and I have to tell you that, in Moria, there are people and garbage and children all involved together. We went to Moria three months ago. Out of 5,000, we found 17,000,000 people. Yesterday we found 20,000 people. I will give you evidence to help: 37% are men, 23% are women and 34% are children. We're talking about kids. Of these, 1,700 are unaccompanied. I have to tell you, 63% of the KYT are families.  I ask a prosthetic question: We are talking about refugees and migrants. 70% in Moria are Afghans. In 2019, 7,500 bombs were dropped in Afghanistan. So what are refugees or migrants? These kids, what are we going to do with them? Are we going to use them as refugees or as immigrants? They're war refugees. And one last thing: We read today in the international press that the Greek government is ordering floating dams. Who pays for these floating dams? This is the first time they have been used against people and, of course, against citizens. It's for combat operations.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: the question asked by raising the blue card. – I also know the situation in moria hotspot. I agree with you that the situation there is very bad, already in 2018 the number of refugees who may be there has been doubled. And I'm asking you, what was the Syriza government doing at the time? How many new centers have she opened? How did she return illegal refugees? How did she speed up the asylum process? When you criticise a government today that has been with the government for less than six months and is trying to take concrete action.

name: Konstantinos ARVANITIS
text: answer a question with a blue card. – This government abolished the Ministry of Migration Policy and re-established it after six months. We denounced that here. So I give you data: In 2016 the government of SYRIZA managed 176,906 people. The current government, in 2019, managed just 60,000 people. I think there is an issue for both the Greek Government and the European Union in managing the problem. We should also point out that we disagree with the closed prison centres.

name: Ioannis LAGOS
text: Madam President, it is brazen to contradict the majority of the Greek people in the Chamber from Greece. More than 65% of Greeks are opposed to illegal immigration. I've been here six months and I've never heard you speak for the rights of the Greeks. I hear you keep talking about illegal immigrants and their rights. Don't the Greeks have rights? You know they can't move home, their homes, their property? You know they're being hunted by illegal immigrants and they've been terrorized? Are you aware that the greek government does not have control over illegal immigration in Greece, but the NGOs have control over it? In fact, two months ago, we went so far as to illegally prohibit the Minister of National Defence from entering a camp in Greece, used as a hotspot, to control the situation. So what are we talking about? For the rights of illegal immigrants? The situation is tragic. They steal, rape, kill. And you humanists here only talk about the Pakistanis, only about the Afghans and about anyone else. So talk about the Greeks and give the Greeks, who live in the homeland of their ancestors, their rights, who have lost them. On the contrary, you are "stroking" Turkey. Turkey is the favorite child. You let them really do what they want. They are filled with unstoppable flows of illegal immigrants to my country and all over Europe. This flag, the Turkish flag, which is not allowed to do what it does, a blood-stained flag—the only thing it deserves is this one; nothing else. Out the Turks, and end the process with them. Let's get this over with.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I am referring you to order, Mr President, and I ask you to familiarize yourself with the Rules of Procedure.

name: Lena DÜPONT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The humanitarian situation on the Greek islands is undoubtedly dramatic. We see increasing arrivals every day, and the uncertain situation around us leaves little hope for relaxation. However, if we blame Greece alone for the situation, it has fallen short for two reasons. Firstly, many bottlenecks are mainly the result of years of failure. The new Greek government has now moved forward here and has carried out evacuations to the mainland, including the 'No child alone' initiative, which has already been mentioned several times today. At the same time, Greece is also raising the issue of the long process – one reason why more and more people are stranded and stranded on the islands. At this point, perhaps a brief remark: it is not helpful if, on the one hand, we criticise Greece for too long procedures and, on the other hand, we also attack any new proposals for speeding up at the same time. This is not in the interests of the people on the islands. What is clear is that Greece's government remains in charge. It is also clear, however, that, secondly, all the other Member States are also obliged to do so. Asylum and migration policy only works through the "and". We need a quick remedy for the people of the islands and a functioning protection of the external borders. We need faster procedures and consistent repatriation. Above all, however, what we need is a Council that is moving, in which there is once again more wrangling for solutions from the states directly and indirectly affected. We, Parliament, the PPE-DE, are ready. Let us use the window of opportunity for a real reform of the asylum and migration package!

name: Pietro BARTOLO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for years we have been talking about the situation on the Greek islands without anything changing. More than 42 000 people trapped, 8 800 minors, of whom more than 1 800 are unaccompanied, many abandoned and unprotected.  But how can the Europe of rights accept that people live in inhumane conditions? How can we allow the Greek Government under the new law to weaken protections and access to asylum and extend the use of detention? The Commission must put pressure on the government to strengthen legal protections and access to health services and guardians for children. There is talk of closing the camps and setting up closed centres on the islands where applicants can be relocated. But why transfer them back to inadequate centres? Instead, we should urgently transfer them to the mainland and promote relocations, especially for children. In the long term, then, we do not need fancy solutions, the only answer is a mandatory automatic relocation system. Let's wake up! We are talking about people, about human beings and not about goods to be stored.

name: Jan-Christoph OETJEN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The conditions on Morea are unacceptable. I think it is a good thing that you, Commissioner, have also noted this. You have, of course, outlined the commission's aid. And here too we agree that this is a lot, but probably not enough to resolve the situation. The signal you are now sending that you are doubling the number of EASO staff is a good signal, but in the end we need the Member States. We need the Member States to get children and young people out of Morea. And I believe that this will require a joint effort by the Member States to achieve this. We cannot allow the situation there to continue in this way, because that is unworthy of the European Union. As you rightly said, we have a situation in which we do not have a crisis. I believe that we must use this window of opportunity so that we can launch a new pact on migration and asylum. Renew has put forward its own proposals. But this does not help the people of Morea in the short term, but in the short term the Member States must take action. And if we don't get them to help the people there and take in people, then doubling the number of EASO staff will not be enough.

name: Tineke STRIK
text: Mr President, the refugees on the Greek islands are traumatised. The inhumane care, the years of waiting and the lack of medical facilities make them victims for the second time. Unaccompanied children are left to fend for themselves and are at great risk. Mind you, I outline a Europe in which we share responsibility for asylum policy. The bad thing is that this situation on the Greek islands has been going on for four years and that it has only got worse rather than better. I welcome the Commission's appeal to the Member States. I am also pleased that there is more support and I also call on the Commission to send not only EASO, but also doctors and other care workers. I also call on the Member States, in particular, to evacuate the people who are there and to distribute them among the Member States, starting with the children. Only then will we be able to really talk about European values again.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, the migratory submersion is a reality: it has hit the Greek islands of the Aegean Sea, whose people are calling for help. On 22 January, a general strike was observed in protest by the inhabitants of Lesbos, Samos and Chios. The situation is untenable: the Moria camp on the island of Lesbos, for example, is home to more than 19,000 migrants, even though it was designed to receive just 3,000. The European Union is responsible for this disaster. It must help Greece to enlarge and renovate these camps in order to treat these people with dignity, while waiting to organise the expulsion from Europe of all those who are illegal economic migrants. On the other hand, we must adopt a policy of firmness and turn back to their port of departure the boats that bring us new contingents: 60,000 migrants who arrived in Greece by sea in 2019 is far too much.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab All I have to do is agree with the many voices that have been heard here today that a new migration pact is needed, that we need a broader reflection on the whole issue, because, after all, at the outset, important politicians from the European Union have invited migrants and, at the same time, have not prepared tools and whole systemic solutions that can deal with this situation. Today, we are indeed in such a situation that we have problems with children, with people who need help, and we do not have effective systemic solutions. All this shows how ineffective the European Union's action in this area has been. Over the years, the number of migrants has been increasing, we have problems in recognizing these people and a lack of systemic solutions, so bilateral agreements are immediately needed, but with those countries from which refugees come, and in addition we need to help on the ground, as Poland or Minister Kempa did: Poland has spent almost two billion zlotys over the years to help these people on the ground and solve the problem systematically.

name: Anne-Sophie PELLETIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, if this situation prevents you from sleeping, then I ask you to find the conviction and the energy to bring together your friends in the Commission and your friends in the Council to find immediate solutions. Andrei Makine said: "Childhood images do not fade or fade." 18,000 people on Moria camp alone for 2,840 in capacity. 5,000 people waiting in vulnerability, but how can we be surprised since there are only three doctors and eight psychologists? The discrepancy between the number of women, men and children taken in and the means put in place create this violence, because by depriving them of everything you have set them up against each other. However, these figures cannot describe the desperation of those present on these islands. Here are the words of a child: "I am so stressed that I lose my memory, every time I close my eyes I have nightmares. All I want is to see my family again." Madam, Greece alone is facing the influx of people in search of a better life and a little respite. The European Union must take its responsibilities and, as a carer, when I hear these stories, when I see the isolation of these people, this European Union revolts me. And tonight, Madam, I am not proud to be an MEP for this dehumanizing European Union.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, your concern about the protection of underage migrants, unaccompanied and those awaiting family reunification is hypocritical, since you and your allies are promoting all imperialist interventions. It is the policy of repression that is currently leading, according to reports, the New Democracy government to design even floating trap dams in the Aegean for migrants and refugees, endangering their lives and paving the way for new long-dead tragedies in the Aegean. We tell you: Don't even think about it! Now take back these inhumane plans.  You, Commissioner, also take a stand. The European Union is jointly responsible. With the EU-Turkey agreement and Dublin, tens of thousands of asylum seekers have been trapped in Greece for so many years in miserable conditions. The false dilemma between closed marzipan-type hells, of the New Republic, and of the open type of Moria, of SYRIZA, is stamped by the European Union and is unacceptable;  Against dangerous EU policy and nationalism, we demand that asylum seekers be taken to their countries of destination, human shelters on the mainland, with quick procedures. No minor homeless, imprisoned, unprotected, without education, away from his family.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I thank you for your statement in which you said that the European Commission wants to support the Greek Government in its efforts to protect its borders from illegal migration. You want to support the Greek Government in building new centres with more dignified conditions for refugees, as well as in better return policy and other measures.  However, I agree with you that this is not enough when it comes to children. Children who are minors and unaccompanied. Unfortunately, since 2018, there have been fewer of them, at that time I visited the island of Lesbos, Athens, Thessaloniki, I visited shelters and refugee facilities. There have been more than 5,000 children today who are minors and unaccompanied. I appreciate the work of the aid workers, but I have also seen the very slow behaviour of the former Greek Government. I respect today's ministers all the more, both the Minister for Migration, the Interior and the entire government, which is working to improve conditions. I welcomed the request of the Minister of the Interior of the Greek Government, who appealed to the ministers of the Member States to help. The Czech Republic was mentioned here. Yes, after a lot of pressure from civil society, the Czech Minister of the Interior also asked and offered some help. And we have hope that the Czech Republic will also help and accept unassanied children who need help.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to Commissioner Johansson that we welcome your strong words as we welcome you to your portfolio. You said it right: the situation is totally unacceptable. But we have been saying this for the last five years in all of the languages of the European Union.  According to the UNHCR, 75 000 people arrived on the Greek islands just last year: 40 000 are in camps meant for barely 5000; 8000 are minors and 2000 are unaccompanied minors. So the situation is not only unacceptable; it is also against the law. It is against the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which is binding law for all the Member States. It’s also against the Reception Directive, which is in effect. That is why we say that the Member States and the Union must help Greece: it’s not the fault of Greece; it is our responsibility. That is why we adopted the Asylum and Migration Integration Fund, which provides for relocation, provides for reunification of families, and provides for protecting children. But more than that, in the mid-term we need to adopt the European Common Asylum System, work on the same, and Dublin, with binding solidarity among Member States and relocation programmes funded by the European Union.

name: Damian BOESELAGER
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to Commissioner Johansson that as we speak, argue, and also scream here, these children that we talked about are still stuck on the islands and there are no transfers. There are also, at the moment, no more guardians taking charge of their legal cases and they are already traumatised and sick when they arrive. So I’m very happy, Commissioner, that you take first measures and want to improve the situation. And I would like to point out to the State Secretary that the Member States are blocking any additional, even voluntary, support at this very moment and so I would ask, State Secretary, that you please press for additional steps here. But I also want to bring your attention to a fact that is overlooked, which is that the Member States are even opting out of the current responsibilities that they have under this law that we already have in place. So, my Member State, Germany, is currently declining 70% of the family reunification cases for these children. Which means that we are basically telling them: even though you have family, you are not welcome here, and this is not okay.

name: Raffaele STANCANELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, respect for the best interests of the child should always be guaranteed in all actions taken by both the European Union and its Member States.  The particularly uncomfortable situation of so many minor migrants is morally unacceptable and, despite the continued efforts of the Greek Government and the Greek people, emergency measures are once again needed. I would like to stress that situations which are repeated with the same intensity for a long time can no longer be described as urgent or emergency, they have unfortunately become structural.  We must put an end to the hypocrisy of those who do not realise, including here in Europe, that it is necessary to take joint initiatives aimed at blocking the departures of irregular migrants, and to concentrate our efforts also and above all financially to create the economic and social conditions so that anyone can remain in their own country, instead of seeking luck elsewhere. Only in this way will the European Union be able to demonstrate that it is in real solidarity with those who really need it.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: Madam President! The situation of refugees on the Greek islands is absolutely catastrophic. Overcrowded camps, open sewers, flooded tents. This is the situation for tens of thousands of refugees. Worst of all is to think of the thousands of unaccompanied children who sit there in the middle of the mud. Sitting alone in the dark. Sits completely without protection from abuse.  It is not just a Greek disaster, it is a European disaster. And it's a disaster that's man-made. The misery on the Greek islands is a direct result of the EU-Turkey agreement and a completely failed EU policy. Ladies and gentlemen, it is time for action. It's time to lift in bunches. Let's help the children in need. Let us have a joint distribution of the refugees and let us stop the humanitarian disaster.

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: – Dear Vice-President, it has now been more than four years since the start of the refugee crisis. But the dire humanitarian situation on the Greek islands with tens of thousands of migrants, including children, in extremely difficult living conditions shows once again how unprepared we are yet to cope with migratory pressure.  Greece is undertaking concrete action to improve the situation and manage migration, but this is certainly not a matter for just one Member State, just as enhanced, irregular migratory pressures on the only land route to the European Union are not a matter for just one Member State. No European country can face the challenge of migration on its own. Because migration concerns the whole Of the European Union and therefore we need a new common, efficient, sustainable and humane system of migration and asylum.  The living conditions of migrants on the Greek islands are completely unacceptable. It is therefore necessary to oppose even more decisively the chains of smugglers and traffickers who are increasingly bringing migrants into life-threatening situations, but it is also necessary to respect the rights and dignity of all migrants, as well as the duty to ensure normal life for the inhabitants of the Greek islands and for all European citizens to be safe. (The Representative agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 171(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, colleagues, of course, the subject we are discussing is very serious, it is tragic, we have children, adults, but you have reached a very important point. You said that no single state can solve the migration problem, and you said one more thing: that we have, we are facing illegal migration. What do you think we should do to stop illegal migration, because, in fact, this complicates things, and this makes those who would be legal unable to have the proper conditions?

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. Thank you very much for asking. I don't think there is any doubt that if we are to reach a new agreement on a fair, humane, effective system of migration and asylum, we must start from those key preconditions, and above all this is the effective protection of the external border of the European Union, since without it even any agreement between the Member States, clearly based on solidarity, but also on accountability will not be possible.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Commissioner, the situation in island structures is inhumane. In 2019, 73,000 refugees and migrants came to Greece — a 100% increase over 2018. More than 40,000 are stranded on the islands, and in many cases they make up more than a quarter of the local population, causing social reactions.  Let's be honest. The EU-Turkey Joint Declaration has failed. After three years of implementation, just 2,000 Syrians have returned from Greece to Turkey, while more than 20,000 have fled from Turkey to Europe. So the one-to-one provided for in the agreement never worked. For some, European solidarity is only about providing money. However, that is not enough. Since the end of the relocation programme in March 2018, only two countries — Portugal and France — have agreed to a voluntary programme.  Commissioner, the Dublin III review should already have been completed on the basis of the European Parliament's decisions. Compromises on such a sensitive issue with countries that undermine solidarity will lead to a stolen review and should not be accepted, because we will have the absurdity of the Greek far-right denouncing you for a lack of solidarity instead of blaming the far-right Poles, who are in the same political group, who do not want the real Dublin review.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, in fact, we are resuming the subject that was discussed a month ago in Strasbourg, exactly within the same parameters. Nothing's happening. In reality, the situation in the Greek islands is extremely difficult, also for the locals, and for the refugees.  I will, however, refer to the approximately 7,600 children who are in the islands and who live in absolutely inhumane conditions. They live in tents, undernourished, poorly hygienic, they get sick and Madam President, Commissioner, children die in Europe because of misery. And we here say we gave Greece $2.1 billion. Yes, they've been given for four years, and the support is insufficient. It is a moment of solidarity. We have an obligation to take children from the Greek islands in all states.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: We are in Europe, in the 21st century, we are in the European Union. I have the honour of being the rapporteur in this House on the report on the state of human rights in the world. We are a Union that stands up for the values of human dignity, also beyond its borders, and demands a lot from its international partners, which I am proud of. How can we claim the right to criticise the way other countries, on other continents, treat their migrants when in the European Union there are islands where the situation of migrant children forces us to talk about a humanitarian crisis. I repeat, we are in Europe in the 21st century, and it is intolerable that the solidarity of all in the Union is not a given when children wade through the mud and the cold. This is not just a Greek problem, it is not just a problem of the countries around the Mediterranean, it is our responsibility to all to guarantee a decent situation for these children. We must give ourselves the means to guarantee this solidarity within the Union, since it is clearly not done in a natural and free way. Solidarity within the Union is done in both directions: it can only be claimed if you are prepared to give it: you do not give, then you do not receive it either. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171, paragraph 8, of the internal regulation))

name: Erik MARQUARDT
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". My question is actually quite simple, because I can agree with your speech and also with the speech before it. However, I believe that we, as a Parliament, could send this message much more strongly if, next time we discuss this situation, we also do so with a resolution where we not only have 60 or 90 seconds, but where we can agree on a text and then perhaps with this text we can also send a strong message, which is exactly what we are asking for. That is why I wanted to ask: will you in your group be committed to ensuring that we can adopt a resolution next time?

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I do not see any problem in this, quite the contrary. Thank you very much.

name: Anna-Michelle ASIMAKOPOULOU
text: (PPE). – Madam President, ‘united we stand, divided we fall’ – a famous phrase, and today in this Chamber we stood united in the face of a threat to our unity: Brexit. And today in this Chamber we stood united in commemorating the International Day for the victims of the Holocaust, and in a united voice, we said: We remember. But when it comes to the migration issue, we are clearly not united. When it comes to dealing with President Erdoğan’s blackmail, using the migration issue, we are not united. At this moment, there are 5 301 unaccompanied minors in Greece, and the Greek Government has asked for European Member States to accommodate 2 500 of them, and only three states have replied. I ask you, dear colleagues, from all Member States and all political parties: have we become so entrenched in our national interest and so thick-skinned that we do not care about children? Frankly, I’m no longer worried about Europe’s unity if we can’t find a solution for 5 000 children; I’m worried about our dignity.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I listened with interest to the Commissioner's speech. It is good that he wants to focus his attention on the subject of underage refugee children, the tragedy is huge, colleagues have described it. I am sure that the new Commission can do a lot of work here, but I would very much urge you, Commissioner, to debate in the Council, too, how bilateral aid works. I am from the Czech Republic, my colleague Shoidrová has already mentioned this. In the Czech Republic, under pressure from civil society, but also with the huge contribution of Mrs Shoidrová, who I want to thank with this, the government ultimately decided to take over the children of refugees from Greece, but the whole process took many weeks and eventually fizzed out, ended in shame, ended in an embarrassing situation where it is now unclear whether the Czech Government ultimately refused to take over the children or was a mistake on the administrative burden on the Greek authorities. So here, too, is the role of the Commission and the Council to work better in a bilater way, so that there are no obstacles to why not, but why help.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, the situation, described by Médecins Sans Sans Frontiers, of several thousand children in refugee camps on the Greek islands is revolting. They are children who fight for food in overcrowded camps, sleep in mud, suffer from severe psychological problems, stop eating, drinking and sleeping. Many self-harm, attempt suicide and some end up even getting an end to their lives. These children and adolescents have fled hunger and war, especially from Afghanistan, Syria, Iraq and Somalia, countries destroyed by military aggression stifers in which the European Union and its powers have great responsibilities. The same European Union which wants to fly the paladin of human rights lives hypocritically with a situation it has created. The overcrowding of these camps does not disconnect from the increasingly selective, restrictive and incapitalised migration policies that the European Union promotes. The European Union therefore has a dual responsibility: what is required is an end to destabilisation, interference and aggression against third countries and scrupulous compliance with international migration law.

name: Ljudmila NOVAK
text: – Madam President! Years ago, I was with the European Parliament delegation on. There were no refugees there at the time, there was tourism, we felt good, people were nice. That is why, of course, I have an understanding of these people, and also of all my Greek colleagues, who know best what conditions their compatriots on the Greek islands now live in.  And when I think of the kids, I have more grandchildren myself, and I certainly feel sorry for the bottom of my heart when I look at these pictures of the children, the hungry and so on. Most of all, of course, the solution is not easy, we have to act, we have to look for different solutions in several areas, but we should certainly take care of the children so that they are not hungry, that we will also offer them an education so that they may one day have a perspective again in their own country.

name: Ylva Johansson
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I’ve been listening very carefully, and I understand from your genuine and committed interventions with a lot of feelings that I’m not the only one that sleeps badly at nights while we have a situation with over 40 000 people living under these unacceptable conditions, many of them children and many of them unaccompanied minors, mostly teenagers. We can’t continue like this, and I understand that we all agree on this. But as I said earlier, lying awake at night will not help anything. We are politicians, we need to act, and I, as the new Commissioner, have a special responsibility to act, of course. So the Commission will, of course, continue to help and support Greece. We have in the last one and a half years spent EUR 35 million to help unaccompanied minors with hotels, with guardians, and we are doing a lot of things, as I also said in my first intervention. But, as many of you have mentioned, we have been in this situation for many years. And at the same time we have, for many years, been in a politically-stuck situation, unable to take the necessary political decisions for a decent way to manage European migration in an orderly way and to have a decent way for solidarity that shows that we all know that we have different geographical realities. Those Member States that are under pressure – for example, these people living on the islands – we need to show solidarity towards the migrants but also, of course, to the Greek people, who are now paying also a very high price. Therefore, of course, first continue to support the migrants and especially the Greek Government and the Greek authorities to change these conditions. But I also think it’s very urgent to find a political solution so that we can actually come together and find this necessary common migration and asylum policy for the European Union. We can’t continue being in a stuck situation. Those who pay the price for this are the people that live under these terrible circumstances on the islands. So there is high pressure on me personally but also on Member States, and I count on your support from Parliament to find these political solutions. Thank you very much for this good debate tonight, and hopefully we can come back to another debate, having more solutions on a decent European way of meeting people that is true to our values, both between Member States and also towards those that are searching for shelter in the European Union.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me first of all thank you for this debate. Your input is very important to help to find workable answers to the current challenges. There is no doubt that the situation on the Greek islands must be addressed in an effective and timely manner. As I have mentioned, I am convinced that the Greek government is committed to improving migrants’ conditions, especially those of children and unaccompanied minors. The new Greek Government announced a new plan designed to protect minors who have arrived in Greece, and we expect the situation to improve soon. I know the Member States and agencies are already extensively supporting all the Greek authorities, and I urge the Greek authorities and the Commission to speed up all the important work they do so that the people most affected can see an improvement in the difficult situation in which they are living. The Presidency will continue working towards a balanced approach between responsibility and solidarity in a comprehensive manner, in view of the upcoming Commission proposals.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I do not know what is most indecent: the unanimous opprobrium thrown at Greece for its alleged lack of generosity towards migrants, or the permanent violation by Turkey of its commitment to control migratory flows, paid for in gold by the European Union. In addition to the 6 billion euros of the refugee facility, there is 3.2 billion in pre-accession funds. All for an indigent result: in 2019, only 189 migrants who crossed the Aegean Sea were actually sent back to Ankara. How can we be surprised in these circumstances that the government of Mitsotakis is finally taking a salutary turn of events? The Lesbos camp, with its 17,000 migrants with a capacity of 3,000, is certainly a borderline case in Europe - the riots of last September have amply demonstrated this. But from Bosnia and Herzegovina to Italy, the threshold of tolerance is far exceeded and the same causes will continue to produce the same effects, as long as Europe does not make the only necessary decisions: border control and return to countries of origin.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. A serious humanitarian crisis is taking place on the Greek islands, which is dramatically affecting children in the first place. Unicef figures need no comment: as of December 31, 2019, the migrant refugee population in Greece has grown by more than 100,000 people, including 40,000 children, including more than 5,000 unaccompanied children. In 2019 alone, 21,800 children arrived by sea (an 80% increase over 2018), of which 3,500 were unaccompanied. Tents and containers set up in reception and identification centres for asylum seekers are overcrowded, the hygiene conditions and violence that occur there are unsustainable, all the more so for the little ones who have already suffered traumatic experiences before arriving on the mainland. It is necessary to support the Greek state in order to improve its capacity for rapid response, but also those associations that can offer targeted support to the specific needs of children, especially if unaccompanied. However, we still cannot manage the emergency: we need a long-term strategy, a common European asylum system that takes into account the best interests of the child, in accordance with international legislation and the moral duty to protect children.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. The Greek islands opposite Turkey have become European prisons for those fleeing. The worst situation concerns children, who suffer devastating physical and psychological consequences. Long stays in overcrowded conditions, separations from siblings or other relatives, deprivation of medical care and essential services expose the most vulnerable to violence, the risk of exploitation, abuse and irreparable harm. In Samos a month ago, the European Court of Human Rights intervened to safeguard the physical and psychological integrity of some unaccompanied refugee children. It has established the timely transfer to a safe place, in compliance with the European Convention on Human Rights, which prohibits inhuman and degrading treatment. Three were transferred only yesterday, one remained on the island. This is no longer the time to talk but to act. Before other Court measures, the EU helps to restore the fundamental rights of the most vulnerable refugees and to restore normality to islanders, through a regular transfer system, giving priority to children.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: in writing. – I used my maiden speech to the Parliament in July of last year to express my grave concerns about the humanitarian crisis unfolding in the Mediterranean. It pains me that six months later I am still having to make the same points, and in the meantime there has been great suffering and grave breaches of fundamental rights in registration camps for asylum seekers. The Moira camp, for example, hosts 19 000 people whilst its maximum capacity is 3 100. The Commission has committed to delivering a new Pact on Migration and Asylum, which of course we welcome. However, the resulting agreement does not absolve the Commission and the Member States from their responsibility to address these deplorable conditions urgently.

name: Janina OCHOJSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. Greece is facing its largest influx of migrants since 2015, when more than one million refugees arrived in Europe. More than 60,000 migrants seeking refugee status arrived in 2019. Camps on the Greek islands are overcrowded, and minors nod off in the streets without access to food, sanitation or electricity. We must remember that we are all responsible for the humanitarian situation on the Greek islands, because it is the result of a lack of solidarity. That is what we are talking about in Parliament about European values, such as equality, unity, human rights, and at the same time we are indifferent to the fate of those in need. We are also talking a lot today about the reform of asylum policy. I agree that it needs to be reformed in order for the verification of migrants to be improved. In particular, new procedures are needed to protect, in particular children, from crime, to ensure access to education and to enable unaccompanied minors to be reunited efficiently with family members in other Member States.  Politics is about developing effective solutions, and that is not about closing borders and condemning people to death at sea. The solution is to help people on the ground in their countries of origin, because if they can provide their loved ones with basic needs, they will not migrate!

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the EU strategy for sustainable mobility and sustainable transport: the measures needed for 2030 and beyond (2020/2518(RSP)).

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am very happy to be back with you again today and to give you a first insight into our reflections on the future of transport and mobility. I would also like to welcome your choice to put sustainability at the centre of this debate, as it perfectly mirrors our common ambitions. As we look to the future, and in line with President von der Leyen’s political guidelines, our policy actions will, on the one hand, be guided by the ambition of the European Green Deal to ensure that transport makes its important contribution to climate neutrality by 2050 and, on the other, by a Europe that is fit for the digital age when it comes to harnessing digital technologies to make mobility smart as well as sustainable.  The strategy on sustainable and smart mobility will have these two objectives at its heart and will guide us towards a transport sector that is fit for a clean, digital and modern economy. The Commission will adopt the strategy later this year, once we have completed our preparatory work, including the public consultation, and received feedback from the stakeholders. What is certain is that the strategy must include ambitious measures aimed at significantly reducing CO2 and pollutant emissions across all modes. It will exploit digitalisation and automation, enhancing connectivity to the next level, and – last but not least – it will ensure safety and accessibility.  Our comprehensive strategy for sustainable and smart mobility will have to be unprecedented in ambition to achieve a 90% reduction in emissions by 2050. I want to share what I see as the four principles that will guide transport’s contribution to the European Green Deal. First: making the transport system as a whole more sustainable, making sustainable alternative solutions available to all citizens and businesses, respecting the polluters-pay principle in all transport mode and, not in the last, fostering connectivity and access to transport for all.  Therefore, in the upcoming transport strategy, I am planning to put forward measures in the following four areas of action. First, to boost the uptake of clean vehicles and alternative fuels for road, maritime and aviation. In this regard, we are already looking into specific initiatives to ensure the availability of marine alternative fuels and sustainable aviation fuels, Second, increase the share of more sustainable transport modes, such as rail and inland waterways, and improving efficiency across the whole transport system. Thirdly, incentivising the right consumer choices and low—emissions practices. Fourth, investing in low-and zero-emissions solutions, including infrastructure.  On the road to a climate-neutral Europe by 2050, it is essential that sustainable and smart go hand—in—hand. Digitalisation is not simply a means to an end. We must take full advantage of the opportunities presented to us by digitalisation and automation, for instance, by increasing traffic efficiency through artificial intelligence or reducing traffic hazards to a minimum, to name only a few. They are the key to cleaner, simpler, smart and safe mobility across all transport modes. Digitalisation also opens the door to mobility as a service and the seamless combination of transport modes for a single journey, encouraging more people out of private cars and onto shared and more efficient forms of transport. We will, of course, be vigilant and watch out for any impact on jobs and skills.  To make this happen, we need accessibility, affordability, connectivity. I am 100% committed to leaving nobody behind as we embark on this green and digital transformation. The Just Transition Mechanism will be key here: it will mobilise EUR 100 billion to address the social and economic effects of the green transition, focusing on the region’s industries and workers who will face the greatest challenges. The connectivity provided by transport is fundamental to freedom of movement in the European Union.  Safety and security: it should go without saying that, while we must embark on a significant reduction of emissions from transport and harness digital opportunities for the sector, safety and security will continue to come first. Our strategy will incorporate measures for maintaining the highest safety and security standards in the world of transport.  When you talk about global leadership, a real market for the green digital solution is emerging, and I want the EU to be a global leader in these areas: from block chain and digital mapping and tracking, to connected and automated vehicles, trains, planes and vessels. To secure our position at global level, we need to take investment in research and innovation very seriously, and we need to work closely with the industry. This are some of my initial remarks on your questions, and of course I am looking forward to your questions and comments.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, thank you very much for your intervention. Thank you also for what you said you would do this year, and i thank you, at the same time, for introducing many important dossiers for transport policy in the Commission programme in the future. It was a very pleasant surprise for me. Future transport policy must first and foremost ensure much-needed mobility and connectivity for the development of the economy. All the measures we must take in the future must, first of all, ensure mobility and then comply with and, of course, the requirements of the Ecological Pact.  There are things you can do without having a lot of costs, not necessarily some market measures, and I can give you some examples. For example, for rail transport, you have freight corridors, which are not developed at the level that should be. You must apply the existing regulation and, at the same time, ensure harmonisation of all regulations and standardisation in this very important mode of transport, because it requires transfer from road to rail.  For road transport, there must be a road map. Predictability is necessary for both industry and consumers. We need to complete the road corridors. For aviation, the Single European Sky, plus a new regulation of state aid for airports, will bring a lot of improvement. Do not forget about transport by river routes, inland waterways, which can bring economic development at the same time, but it can also bring reduction in emissions.

name: Johan DANIELSSON
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner Vălean, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for her excellent report. A change to a greener and more sustainable transport sector will be crucial to achieving our climate objectives. By 2050, freight transport is expected to increase by 80% and passenger transport by 50%. At the same time, the EU should achieve net-zero emissions.  Then taxes and levies on fossil fuels and on different types of emissions will not be enough, but we must also present a positive vision of the green transition through investment. We need to invest in infrastructure. We must invest in alternative fuels and ensure that sustainable conversion is possible in all modes of transport, be it road, air, rail or sea.  I look forward to working with the Commission in line with what you proposed in your work programme to expand the railways, increase the proportion of rail freight, expand the charging infrastructure to ensure the electrification of our road transport and to ensure that europe also leads the conversion of aviation through alternative fuels, but also the electrification of shorter flights. Transport is the bloodstream of our internal market. Now it must also turn green.

name: José Ramón BAUZÁ DÍAZ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her speech, which has very clearly marked the lines to be followed, many of which we obviously share. Ladies and gentlemen, let me quote the following sentence, which I quote verbatim: "Who else travels by plane is probably the one who has the most resources or who sees their tickets paid for by the company". These are the irresponsible statements that the Vice-President of the Spanish Government made yesterday in an interview. An unfortunate anti-aircraft rhetoric that what it does is pretend to question the citizens who make use of the plane to move simply and simply, and are questioned simply for being free. Speeches like this, which we do not share at all, what they do is search, blame and criminalize not only the industry, but also all those who use certain goods or services simply because they are free and have the ability to choose.  The criminalization of transport not only ruins truckers or pilots, but also leads to direct bankruptcy of foreign trade, our exports, domestic trade and, of course, the island regions. I come from some islands, from the Balearic Islands, and we need safe, reliable, fast transport, in this case, as is that of airplanes. And we do it either out of necessity or because we want to. Just because we're free citizens. Today more than ever, from the European institutions we need to move away from populismos, and that transport is not seen as a threat but as an opportunity; I'm not going to say it as a necessity anymore.  We need to think constructively. We need to rely on new technologies, new opportunities provided to us, also biofuels or alternative fuels. Banning, pointing, criminalizing, is never the solution. And precisely those of us here have that responsibility.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, transport is 30% of greenhouse gases. It is the only sector that has not reduced its greenhouse gases since 1990 and, at the same time, no Member State is complying with the Paris Agreements. This phenomenon has also triggered a second dynamic, which is terrible since we have the disease of the 21st century before our eyes, especially this air pollution: 800,000 premature deaths each year. And so, Commissioner, you are talking about the Green Deal for Europe. I agree, but don't make it a Green Washing at all! The ecology of illusion deserves the ecology of solutions. In this roadmap of the Green Pact for Europe, we need boldness, we must be ambitious, attack where it hurts. So yes, we're going to tackle things that hurt, but we need answers. First, the aviation sector: it is high time it entered the ETS (ETS) system. And let's go further to implement a real kerosene tax. It is your services that have shown that a kerosene tax can bring 27 billion euros a year to the state budget. Isn't it great in terms of raising money to get what we need? Relaunching freight, boosting hard urban mobility with more public transport, more bike lanes? Madam President, I conclude very quickly: I do not accept or will not accept that the Commission will take its courage to hand us a text on the Eurovignette, a text which has been torpedoed by the Council, voted by Parliament. Thank you.

name: Roman HAIDER
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Unfortunately, the paper that the Commission has presented here is not particularly green, nor is it a good deal. On the contrary, implementing this draft puts millions of jobs at risk, without contributing in any way to the environment or climate protection. To put it bluntly, the Commission is questioning the economic foundations of almost 500 million citizens – for nothing. I am particularly angry that the citizens and their needs play no role at all in these high-flying commission plans. People need their vehicles to get to work – every day. They need their vehicles to earn a living. And it is precisely these millions of commuters who take this project out of the way of the proverbial Christmas goose. These plans are not only anti-economic, they are also antisocial. They make mobility a luxury asset.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The respected Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. A key element of the EU's mobility strategy should be the investment in environmentally friendly means of communication, particularly as regards public transport. We have modern European know-how, especially when it comes to rail vehicles, as exempled by bydgoszcz Pesa. It is worth investing in the development of such enterprises.  The future of transport is also smart vehicles and infrastructure that guarantee the highest possible safety for pedestrians and drivers, as well as greater efficiency of freight transport, which cannot be achieved by limiting competition through a mobility package.  2030 is a very ambitious caesarean with such a complex and expensive agenda. In many regions, basic transport needs have still not been met, safe roads are lacking and the average age of cars in the European Union is 11 years. I hope that the Commissioner will remember all this. Looking ahead cannot be a strategy to move forward from the current problems we have found.

name: Elena KOUNTOURA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mrs Vălean, thank you very much for the presentation. I hope we have very good cooperation in the years to come. In the debate on the future of transport, we must set three priorities which are inextricably linked: firstly, clean transport for climate and human health. We know that transport accounts for 27% of greenhouse gases, at a time when air pollution, particularly in urban centres, causes millions of premature deaths. Secondly, there is no European strategy aimed not at the connectivity of all Member States, but above all of island and remote regions. The situation is dramatic. Already today the costs borne by these populations are enormous. All they are asking for is equal conditions and opportunities with other Europeans. Thirdly, a socially just transition. If we do not create countermeasures and welfare for the weakest, we will lose acceptance of society. Transport must not become a luxury for the privileged. The key to success is investment in new technologies, innovation and research. We can't waste any more time. We have to move from words to action.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Vice-President, rail is a picture of the state, that is, if we want to see the state of a country, let's look at its railway. When it comes to national transport, I am afraid that Croatia is far from ready for the future of sustainable transport, unfortunately the facts of the Croatian transport development strategy from 2017 testify, and there it says: "The railway fleet is on average more than 30 years old, 70% of locomotives will reach the end of their working life in the next ten years. Due to its age, the fleet destroys railway infrastructure. Only 18% of the total length of the lines allowed is the maximum speed designed. Further, train speeds of up to 160 km/h are allowed only at 7% and up to 100 km/h on only 12 % of tracks. The system renewal required every eight to 10 years has not been carried out for the past 35 years. The existing business of the railway is not sustainable without state aid. Unfortunately, colleagues, this is what chronic decades of corruption looks like in practice. You can see it on the railroad.

name: Barbara THALER
text: – Madam President, dear colleagues, mobility is an indicator of wealth, opportunities and prosperity. Mobility brings individuals and consequently Europe closer together.
