Mobility itself is not a problem - it’s quite the opposite.  Dear Commissioner, our European transport system has to stay affordable, reliable and sustainable. And let me share three ideas on this:  Firstly, I think we all agree that our railway system can contribute to our shared goals. However, we need to cut red tape, to an enormous extent, we need to unleash competition and we need to tear down national borders. I know the Commission is well aware and I know you are committed to solve this problem. But how exactly are you planning to proceed? Secondly, for 20 years the average European household has been spending 13% of their monthly available income on mobility, while at the same time better technology reduced our CO2 emissions by 25%. How are you going to ensure that the expenses for our citizens will say will stay the same in the future? And lastly, now I switch back to mother tongue.  Wir wurden nicht gewählt, um Mobilität zum Problem zu machen. Wir wurden gewählt, um die Probleme der Mobilität zu lösen. Seien Sie sich sicher, Frau Kommissarin, in uns haben Sie einen starken Partner darin.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: – Madam President, the future of mobility has to be CO2 neutral. We can reach that only through new technologies and alternative fuels, and electrification will not be possible without the corresponding infrastructure. Therefore, Madam Commissioner, I urge you as soon as possible to come forward with the Alternative Fuels Infrastructure Directive, which we had seven years ago but which failed due to the destructive approach of the Council. Furthermore, I want to raise one more issue, which is the importance of the Trans-European Networks Directive or Regulation. This is also in preparation – we know that. I was the rapporteur eight years ago, and at that time we had different goals. Now we have different goals as well. Therefore we have to support, with the Trans-European Networks guidelines, also these targets and these goals that I mentioned before. We have to fund the smart and clean infrastructure also within the Transport and TEN-T guidelines as well, and the funding has to be there.

name: Caroline NAGTEGAAL
text: Mr President, give us clarity. That is what I hear very often from the barge skippers in Moerdijk and in Delfzijl. But also in my own city of Rotterdam. "We want to," they tell me, "and actually rather today than tomorrow." Inland navigation in the Netherlands, but certainly also in Europe, is very keen to make that step towards sustainable fuels. At the moment, it is really only the lack of clarity from Europe that prevents it from doing so. Whether it's hydrogen, LNG or electric propulsion. Or perhaps that most brilliant find we don't know yet. It doesn't really matter, as long as European regulations allow it and the infrastructure just gets there.  That's why I'm standing here now. I really want Europe to stop blaming inland navigation. I am actually sure that the revision of the TEN-T directive and the alternative fuels directive will allow all those hard-working and indispensable barge skippers to do what they want, namely to leave a sustainable Europe to the next generation.  And my question to you, Commissioner, is therefore: 'Do you agree with me that hydrogen, LNG or those other possible alternative fuels offer opportunities for our inland waterway sector to become more sustainable and thus to gain ample space? If so, how do you see this in the light of the upcoming TEN-T directive and the Alternative Fuels Directive?

name: Ciarán CUFFE
text: – Thank you, Madam President. The future of transport must be affordable, accessible, healthy and clean: not my words, but the words of our President, Commissioner Ursula von der Leyen, and I agree with that sentiment. I want to see it delivered. So let’s start with walking, move on to cycling and then invest in quality public transport. It’s not rocket science. If our transport systems work for children, if they work for older people, then we’re on the right road to sustainability. But we do have to move away from a car-centric vision of transport and mobility, and I want you, Commissioner, to place a clear focus on active travel and safer, low—carbon mobility solutions. We have to move away from our obsession with mega projects and focus more on the small things that make a difference in different regions around Europe. An EU strategy must not repeat the mistakes of the past – endless motorway and airport expansions and subsidies for pollution industries – so let’s offer a positive vision for how people can move around.

name: Philippe OLIVIER
text: Madam President, let me remind you of a simple truth: the cleanest energy and the energy that is not consumed. You are proposing to reduce transport pollution, you are right. But how can you not think that you have a certain schizophrenia, because having realized that the planet is suffocating with the development of transport, you are working hard to implement a model based on free trade, nomadism, that is to say in practice the infinite development of transport, and we see in the world, the ballet of super-cargoes sweeping goods and even waste. You are not talking about citizens, but only about consumers, reducing man to this consumerist function. It is this mercantilist conception of man that places you in full ecological contradiction. In globalism, we oppose localism that invites us to produce, consume, retreat on the spot. To nomadism, we contrast the happiness of living on his land with his affections and traditions, to your hyper-consumerism we oppose a sobriety that, as Pierre Rabhi reminds us, can be a source of happiness. Thank you.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, this debate seems to have been written by Mr Franz Kafka. I believe you know this Czech writer. I hear and see the same people who voted and pushed against the interests of Central and Eastern Europe, Romania, Hungary, Bulgaria, Poland, the Baltic Republics, Spain, Portugal the Mobility Package. These same people are talking about a green deal and complaining about polluting transport. And they're complaining about rising emissions. How can they not go up when you voted to walk thousands of empty trucks thousands of miles across Europe? How will these emissions not rise? One of them isn't true.  You can't drive empty trucks and ask for a green deal. What's it called: hypocrisy, duplicity, fat-heartedness? I don't know, tell us! What is happening before our eyes is a real fake, and you, Commissioner, have a big problem. You have to fight the Mobility package, which was made in the interest of carriers from outside the European Union such as Russia, such as Turkey, who take business. You don't listen to carriers – the carriers from Bulgaria, from Romania, from Poland and from the Baltic states, because there is lobbying and it is ugly and it should not happen.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, mobility policies are crucial for the quality of life of the population, for the functioning of the economy and for reducing anthropic impacts on the environment. From the perspective of economic, social and territorial cohesion, mobility needs at local, regional and national level must necessarily be taken into account. The European Union has been putting a growing focus on the so-called trans-European networks under pressure from the major economies that dominate the single market, while reducing the resources needed for what remains to be done, and it is very much at the level of local, regional and national mobility, especially in areas such as the railway or the underground in cities. The so-called European Ecological Pact, despite much propaganda, has a clamorous failure on the issue of mobility. There is no sustainable mobility without a strong commitment to public transport, without the massive transition of users from individual transport to public transport. Well, not once has the so-called European Ecological Pact spoken of public transport. We hope that the mobility strategy that is here will correct these distortions.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: –Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Velean, Europe, certainly has to be at the forefront of a transport paradigm capable of reconciling efficiency and environmental sustainability. But in Catalonia, when we think about the future of transport, the first thing that comes to mind is the Mediterranean Corridor. The social and economic actors, both in Catalonia and Valencia, have never stopped insisting and working on the need for this connection, which is highly strategic for Europe. It has been included in TEN-T for ten years, but has not yet been completed.  We have long seen how investment is curbed from the Spanish state; a comprehensive master plan is lacking for the 2020-2030s, from France to Algeciras; it is not necessary to know the date of the new connection of the port of Barcelona, which has been planned for more than twelve years, the new terminal of the old Llobregat channel, etc. Commission speeches are always welcome and important, but regulations are useless if they are not enforced. They have no real effect, if they are not followed by good implementation by the Member States. We hope that the European Commission will be really firm in this regard.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you, Commissioner, for joining us today. We are talking about the future of mobility. Today, however, I would like to raise an issue which is of particular interest to the citizens of Europe and on which I have received countless questions from my constituents in recent months. That is the subject of environmental badges. We are seeing many cities in Europe, in the European Union, introducing their own systems. In Strasbourg, for example, we have this. Anyone who, like me, travels by car every time before Strasbourg week had to apply for a badge there. Anyone who, like me, travels here to Brussels by car has had to register here, and we have that in countless cities within the European Union. We, the European People's Party, have asked the Commission on several occasions in recent years – these were your predecessors, whom we asked – whether a) this is in line with European rules and (b) whether this patchwork is in the interests of our European Union. Many citizens are afraid that if they enter cities, they will receive severe penalties if they do not register. Registration is not always easy either. And here I would ask you: for all the foresight that we are hearing here today on the various issues, and which are also important, that we also take note of these current issues and that you, as the new Commissioner – I have met you in such a way that you really want to make an effort for the well-being of the citizens – take up this issue and give us feedback and review it.

name: Giuseppe FERRANDINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Green Deal cannot and must not be a mere political spot. We are fully aware of the climate challenges to be faced and it is urgent to correct the pull of Community policies quickly and effectively. I call on the Commission to adopt a more ambitious and determined attitude, starting with Eurovignette, which is blocked by national logic that is coerg with the long-term vision of the Green Deal. We all know that transport is responsible for a quarter of the Union's emissions. We need specific investments in rail, air and sea transport. Furthermore, the Commission's current position on intermodal transport is still not sufficient. Parliament has already reiterated that a greater economic effort is needed to achieve the 2030 targets.  I am also very concerned that punishing the polluter more could turn into unfair taxation that falls exclusively on the final consumer, instead of being an incentive for less impacting technologies to develop.  Once again, the investment required to link the peripheral areas of Europe, such as the south of Italy, seems to be insufficient. We therefore call for an increase of EUR 6 billion in the CEF mechanism, as Parliament has already proposed.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, efficient, sustainable and clean mobility of people and goods is one of the keys to the competitiveness of our economy. It is an essential tool to fight climate change and guarantees freedom of movement. We are leaders in many transport technologies, and maintaining that position forces us to innovate, to create the world's first integrated mobility system. This requires betting on intensive digitization, industrial innovation to decarbonize vehicles and connect them with each other, infrastructure and users, and the training of new professionals. You have to evolve in transport mode management to start talking about mobility. New business models will appear that will allow users, in a single operation, to solve their needs from the first to the last kilometer. A transformation that also requires a change from which we are all protagonists and that begins at ground level. That is why I insist that you add wills from the bottom up and rely on the institutions closest to the public to move forward. And, of course, commitments and agreements must be fulfilled which are key to this development: the trans-European transport networks, the Single Sky, the Galileo network, the rail package; we are committed to the Green Pact, but it will be left alone in good words if the Member States continue to block the foundations of this transformation. You must be the protagonist to demand that they comply.

name: Tilly METZ
text: Madam President, Luxembourg is the first European country where public transport will be free from 1 March. Access to practical and effective alternatives to travel is essential to make citizens want to change their mode of transport. Access for all and the affordable cost of transport are essential, but other investments are also needed. We have to make sure that the infrastructure is there to easily switch from train to bike, train to electric car or train to tram. Equally necessary is the introduction of reduced tariffs across Europe for low-carbon transport, such as rail, especially for students, and the fair taxation of polluting means of transport. Finally, there is also a need for a strengthening of intra-European train lines and night trains. This strategy must be an integral part of the Green Pact. This is a concrete area in which Europe must improve the quality of life of citizens.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We listened to an interesting presentation by the European Commission on its strategy for transport and mobility. I would like us all to be able to develop a coherent approach in this area. Experience so far has shown that, in order for infrastructure projects to be guaranteed success, they must first of all obtain the consent of the Member States and be provided with sources of funding. Therefore, in the context of the ongoing discussions on the new financial perspective, the Cohesion Fund and Instrument C are of particular importance. In the first speech by the President of the European Commission, there were few references to rail transport. So does the European Commission envisage taking action, for example, to support investment in high-speed rail and to create a European central plan for high-speed rail networks in the European Union? If you anticipate action, what and when?

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for the presentation. Let me tell you that sustainability is based on three pillars. First of all, of course, the ecological issue, which was widely disseminated in your speech. We must all subscribe to the Green Pact for Europe and ensure that tomorrow goods, in particular, are transported more by rail than by road, but also that there is a tax on kerosene - personally, I am all for it - so that there is fair taxation and that we can promote certain modes of transport. Second, sustainability is also about the economy, jobs, families and businesses that depend directly on the transportation sector. Yes, we must ensure that we have this special attention for business and for employment in the strategy that will be carried out with the help of digital technology. Finally, there is the social or democratic aspect. Yes, transport is a democratic issue for many of our regions: those that are landlocked, those that are neglected, those where citizens cannot travel because there is a lack of means of transport, whether public or private. This is a democratic issue for Europe: Commissioner, you have a very important role to play in this area, to ensure that every citizen tomorrow has mobility solutions close to home, close to home, close to work. At that time, yes, faith in Europe will grow thanks to these solutions which will be brought by you, by the Commission and by all the players in mobility. It is therefore also a democratic issue beyond the ecological and economic stakes. (Applause)

name: Isabel GARCÍA MUÑOZ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the revision of theRTE-T Regulation will be one of the key pillars of the next strategy for sustainable mobility and transport and should be aligned with the new objectives of the Green Pact. Concrete legislative proposals to enhance the railway are necessary for more efficient and sustainable freight and passenger transport, for which the drive for multimodality is essential, and for it to improve interconnection with ports, airports, with logistics platforms, urban nodes, with island regions and also with rural areas. Specific guidelines are needed to ensure that all users have access to electric vehicle charging points, even in depopulated areas. Simplification of administrative processes is needed to work more effectively on cross-border projects. And strong financing instruments, such as the next CEF, where 60% of its endowment is already needed to promote sustainable and intelligent mobility.  I therefore stress the importance of maintaining Parliament's position during the CEF negotiations.

name: Clotilde ARMAND
text: – Madam President, any European transport strategy must take into account our environmental objectives, but also economic realities. There are countries in Europe, such as the country I represent, Romania, that do not have a connection to the European motorway network. There is no motorway in Romania that crosses the border to the rest of the European area. There is no highway to cross the Carpathian Mountains to connect the country's regions.  It is not about road densification projects, it is about a minimum that an economy needs to thrive. Even if we move investments towards rail and river transport - investments, moreover, very large and long-lasting - we will not be able to circumvent this need, completing the European road network to a minimum. It is the right of all European citizens to benefit from accessibility in transport. The European strategy must allow for a fair green transition.

name: Anna DEPARNAY-GRUNENBERG
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Reshaping the transport sector in order to have any chance of achieving the Paris climate change targets is without question a mammoth task. We must start now. Let us start today by making the most obvious: without a massive strengthening of the railways in Europe, we will not be able to transform the transport sector in a sustainable way. Be it the need to develop rail infrastructure, and in particular the gaps in cross-border rail transport, or the creation of fair competition between modes of transport. All I am saying is that we are pricing in externalities in order to put an end to the old and now anachronistic disadvantage of the railways. Today I would like to stress the importance of night trains. They are often the only concrete climate-friendly alternative to intra-European flying. Often dismissed as romantic, it turns out that there is a real market, with high demand. You are rightly experiencing a renaissance in Europe today. Where is the Commission with ideas to stimulate this trend in a very concrete way? I would have a lot in mind: boosting vehicle financing, public service-oriented track prices, continuous ticketing. Let's work on it together!

name: Raffaele STANCANELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, transport and mobility are the lifeblood of our economy. The right to safe, efficient and sustainable transport is fundamental, and the European Union must do everything in its powers to ensure that it is guaranteed at affordable prices that allow the free movement of people and goods.  I would like to take advantage of this debate on the European Union's mobility and transport strategy for 2030, to remind the European Commission that there are certain European regions where it is necessary to build the missing links and eliminate the existing bottlenecks that still hinder the proper functioning of the internal market.  Sicily is characterised by insularity and an objective economic disadvantage for its businesses and its citizens. For this reason, the European Union must support effective recognition of territorial continuity with regard to air transport and finance the investment in the construction of the bridge over the Straits of Messina as a necessary and indispensable infrastructure for the rail link within the Ten-T European corridor.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Madam President, when we are speaking about the Green Deal, I think that the decarbonisation of transport will be one of the biggest challenges. We know that, all the time, emissions from the transport sector have been increasing, and we also know that the need for mobility is increasing all the time. But I very much agree with the Commissioner that we already have solutions available: we have alternative sustainable fuels, and here I think it is very important that we have a very technology—neutral approach, because we have very different regions in in Europe and also different modes of transport with different needs. We have digital innovations, as the Commissioner said, and we can make mobility more smart and effective because of these new innovations. We also have the possibility to invest more: very modern, smart, fast connections in the transport sector, and here I’m also asking for your support, Madame Commissioner. As you know, Parliament is very willing to invest in more cross—border transport connections in Europe, and now we are negotiating on the next MFF, it is very important that we are really investing in transport connections also.

name: Petar VITANOV
text: – Madam President, European citizens want to live in a peaceful world, in an environmental environment, in a socially responsible and people-minded Union. Quality of life, cleaner air, water are linked to a substantial transformation in the field of transport by achieving effective and interconnected mobility, but also clean and low-carbon mobility. We need to do our utmost to make the transition from high-emission transport to zero-emission transport, such as rail transport. Through an action plan to revive it, we need to ensure regulations to unleash the potential of the passenger and cargo strand, which will improve coordination and reduce bureaucratic setbacks.  Targeted investments are therefore needed to be invested in infrastructure and digitisation to make the transition from road to rail. We need to improve the connectivity of the European rail network so that it becomes a more attractive way to travel medium and long distances at an affordable price. Finally, it is unacceptable for European citizens to be held hostage to the incompetence of their own governments, because it is absolutely unacceptable in the 21st century for the distance between two European capitals such as Berlin and Sofia to be taken in 3-4 days.

name: Pablo ARIAS ECHEVERRÍA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, transport is a basic sector for the functioning of our economy, the internal market and trade, and its competitiveness, which is fundamental to manufacturing and the export of goods. Without transport, the internal market does not exist, but, moreover, as the Treaty contains, it is a fundamental element of territorial and social cohesion. Therefore, the new strategy on mobility and transport, in addition to having as its main objective the protection of the environment, must take these elements into account.  If we are to achieve the ambitious goal of achieving the total decarbonisation of our economy by 2050, we must reduce pollution and improve the air quality of cities. We need safer, more sustainable and more efficient mobility, but also reforms; we cannot create more problems for citizens, we must certainly give them solutions. Our cities will need to change to foster cleaner and more efficient modes of transport, incorporate alternative fuels, electrify transport, and integrate new forms of mobility. And in that sense, it is necessary — and I want to do it here today — to highlight the plan of the City of Madrid (MADRID 360): a comprehensive plan to achieve safe, sustainable and efficient and even mobility. An example of how to get things right, which many cities in the Union will have to take note of.

name: Vera TAX
text: Mr President, in my region, there has been a major loss of jobs in the car industry for the past year, and 1700 jobs have been lost there. Those people are at home now. The reason for this is the uncertainty about mobility in Europe. In China, there is no doubt. At the very moment, many jobs are being created by investment in sustainability. That's what we have to do now. The EU's mobility and transport strategy should be about employment. The production of sustainable vehicles creates thousands of new jobs. This must be an important part of our strategy. So I therefore call on you not only to invest in sustainable mobility, but also in the employment of the future.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to congratulate you Commissioner for your hard work from day one and bringing back to normal the work of the Directorate-General for DG MOVE, including the legislative work, including the mobility package procedure, which in the past crossed some boundaries that shouldn’t be crossed. I know the future belongs to green policies. I know the future belongs to green transport but someone proposed, just a minute ago, that we should decrease airline routes, we should tax kerosene and, instead, we should be building bicycle lanes. I would like to see a bicycle lane between Amsterdam and Sofia instead of the plane. But now back to the topic. A lot has been said about CO2 ceilings, about strategies, about priorities, I would like to say something about road safety. Road safety and the roads are responsible for more casualties than any other disease which is attacking humankind now. So, we need safer roads and better education for drivers. This can happen only with EU funds with significant amounts in them, so we should provide safer roads in a better condition and a EU—wide strategy on how to educate young drivers.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mrs Vălean, let me express my pleasure that you are here with us today. I am sure that you, more than all of us in this Chamber, understand that sustainable mobility requires investment in green public transport, and indeed at an accelerated pace. Today, only 9% of Europe's urban transport fleet is electric. By 2035 we will be over 50%. But until then, 15 years have elapsed. For these 15 years, therefore, cities such as Thessaloniki — my city — need reliable urban transport. Urban transport is needed to provide systematic and accurate services to citizens. The lack of these transports, combined with the old age of the car fleet, which is reflected in countries such as Greece, which have had an impact from the crisis, shows that there is a serious investment gap. This can be bridged by the participation of the new 2021-2027 budget, by mobilising the private sector and by all the tools given to us by the Green Agreement. We need targets that will be achieved this time. We need low-cost public transport accessible to all.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, let me congratulate Commissioner Vălean on its priority on sustainable transport, waterway transport. In this regard, I ask him the following request.  Germany built a canal called the Rhine-Main-Danube Canal. Romania built another canal that connected the Danube with the Black Sea, the Port of Constanta. Through the two canals we have 2,900 km of waterway that is not in use.  Why is that? Because the unification of the regulations of the Danube Commission and the Rhine Commission has not been negotiated. I ask the European Commission to try to harmonise the two committees and unify the traffic regulations.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course even five years ago, and four years ago, we heard speeches in much the same way: what we need to do to have sustainable, sustainable, environmentally friendly transport. And tonight I heard a lot. The problem is that we have heard less about how to do this, and I think that is what we need to focus on.  You said, Commissioner, that we need to strengthen connectivity, but we must first create it, because we have disconnected areas. We need to see how we connect all of Europe. It has been said here: there are countries that do not have motorways, there are countries that have half or three quarters of the railway network decommissioned. What's our schedule? How much funding does the transport sector receive in the new financial framework, because we cannot otherwise, together with the Member States?  And there's one more thing. A lot of things get stuck in the council. The Heads of State and Government need to understand that we work here in Parliament for nothing, we come up with projects, we come up with proposals, you come, the Commission, with proposals, and everything gets stuck. Only in a partnership between the Member States and the Commission can we really make sustainable and sustainable transport.

name: Valter FLEGO
text: - Dear Vice-Presidents, Commissioners, we know that the European Union's strategy of zero traffic deaths by 2020 aimed to reduce the death toll by half as much as in 2010. Unfortunately, this will not happen because, here, in 2018 only 25,000 people died in traffic, or about 500 people a week. Among the countries where the most people die, unfortunately, along with Romania is Croatia. The EU average is 49 deaths per million inhabitants, and in Croatia 89. And it is important to emphasize that as many as 94% of all cases are caused by human error. That is why I think it is crucial, on the one hand, to invest in road infrastructure, but on the other hand, in advanced technologies in vehicles, in digital technology, or in new opportunities so that they can reduce this terribly high mortality figure.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I would like to thank you very much for mentioning road accidents in your speech. I am another MEMBER who is talking about this here. Understanding the need to build a low-carbon, environmentally harmless transport system, we must not forget that in 2017 25 000 people died on the roads in the European Union, the most in Romania, Bulgaria and also in my country, Poland. An opportunity for the Commissioner, an opportunity for all of us is to build the Via Carpathia corridor, a much-needed north-south corridor that will allow people and goods to move faster and better between north and south. You have a lot of room to show off here. I encourage you to support this project and please take into account all issues related to the mortality of everyday life. 25 000 funerals a year is a shame for the European Union.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Madam President, I too wish the Commissioner every success. Today was a sad day for us in Parliament. We broke up, after 47 years together, from Britain. But I believe that the Commission, through the objectives it has set itself, must achieve extremely important targets and contribute much more to the strengthening of the Union, to have a strong Union through which we can move as safely and quickly as possible from east to west, from north to south.  I come up with a practical proposal, which comes in line with the Commission's aspirations through the European Green Pact: if possible, to implement a number of recommendations whereby at least national and European institutions install stations for charging electric vehicles. It is a first step to support this industry.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I say to the House: thank you for this interesting debate and the pertinent comments. I have carefully noted them and am very much encouraged by your interest in the subject. I do recognise what you are saying on all the ideas. We are working on them in the Commission in order to put forward this strategy by the end of the year. All the points are valid. And, as I said at the beginning, for this strategy to be successful we need to have everyone on board. So it needs to be just, and it needs to how create new jobs, it has to be accepted. And this will be part of our thinking. Listening to you all, it also becomes very clear that there are baskets of measures for each mode. There is not merely one solution for everything, and we have to carefully blend and balance several measures in order to achieve smoothly the best possible outcome in the short term. Because people are expecting to see results rather quickly from our work on the sustainability of transport. Many of you stressed the importance of the TEN-T infrastructure. And I can only say that I share this view, where it is needed, because it is incomplete, be it for various modes of cross-border interconnection. We know that we need to do more there in order to help create the missing links, which are not necessarily economically sustainable. And this would be the role of the European Union to add and support the missing links. And why not eliminate the barriers, which are cross-border, in order to make flows easier? The Commission announced – or at least I’m telling you – that we’re are going to revise the TEM-T infrastructure in 2021. Many Members mentioned alternative fuels infrastructure and alternative fuels as such. I think this is also very much in connection with aviation, which was intensely mentioned. We have to keep in mind that both aviation and maritime transport are global businesses. Once more, we need to understand there are baskets of measures, there are technological advances and there are alternative fuels. We need to very carefully look into them and into the market and the volume of this kind of fuels on the market, so that they could have an important uptake. But these are all things we are looking at. A lot of you talked about implementation. Of course it is all for nothing if we adopt legislation which is not implemented in the end. So many countries are very late in implementing important things in regulation. We could mention railway signalling as just one example. Many Members mentioned the fact that there are files which are blocked by the Council. I hope I can assure you that, for example, the single European sky is something I’m trying to lobby for and promote in each meeting I have with any representative of the Member States. We have it on the table and we’d like very much to see it moved forward by the Croatian presidency. This is something I’m insisting on, and I really hope we will have movement here. The same is true with the Eurovignette, we haven’t withdrawn the Eurovignette, we are trying to lobby for it in order to benefit from all the good work done. We have to push forward so that the Council will have a general approach – hopefully – by June. Because the Eurovignette or the single European sky are the kind of things which will make a difference in road transport or improving the efficiency of air traffic. And this will have a concrete impact on sustainability and on the reduction of emissions or on internalising the externalities in road transport. Road  safety was mentioned. Of course, road safety has to be at the core of our activity. And what we are going to propose, or work on, is a safe system, which is an integrated approach towards safety in transport. Because, as was mentioned by several people here, there are so many elements which together constitute the environment for safety in transport. All this needs to be taken into account.  All the ideas I heard are very good. And the last word would be on the fact that all the industries in connection with transport as such are the backbone of our economy. We need to make it more sustainable and smart, but keep in mind that it is competitive and it has to remain as such. And for this industry – as it was mentioned – we need measures which are predictable so people will know, investors will know, what it coming  so they can plan in advance for 10 or 20 years.  I also had some particular questions from Mr Schulze on low-emission zones or the harmonising of vignette systems. This is something we are working on. Because the idea of having low-emission zones is good. Yes it is, but it is true that for people moving around not knowing the system is a deterrent or an obstacle. So what we are looking at is to propose a harmonisation of these systems for urban areas. For the Eurovignette, we have already said that we would like to support the Eurovignette.  The question on inland waterways raised by Mr Băsescu: inland waterways need to become the new big thing because I think they are underused. You are absolutely right, because inland waterways together with transport with rail are the most sustainable modes we have. And new progress on inland waterways is needed in terms of sustainability of the ports and the vessels and new intelligent traffic systems. All these are there, we are looking into them. And you are right that the Danube Commission, which is 70 years old – or something similar, you know would know better – has a different regulation. But I promise you, we are going to look into harmonisation. I think because they are non-EU members it is not easy but it is absolutely needed. So thank you very much for the suggestion. So this would be, honourable Members, in a nutshell, my reaction to your comments. I trust that you will get involved in the work on such a sustainable transport system for the future. And, Madam President, consider this my invitation to you to contribute to this work. So thank you very much and I hope will have new occasions to go more in depth on each of the subjects touched upon this evening.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: Writing. – Transport connectivity and mobility in the EU are undoubtedly a fundamental lever for the economic development of the Member States.  However, while realising that the transport sector is responsible for almost 30% of all CO2 emissions in the EU, with road transport representing a 72% share, and taking into account the ambitions set by the EU in achieving a carbon-free future, future EU action in the field of transport and mobility will be essential. In this context, I would particularly stress the urgency of the EU's efforts to strengthen the development of quality public transport (urban, long-distance and international), which should be particularly affordable and physically accessible to every resident in the EU, in particular people with disabilities and those living in more peripheral areas. However, the solution is not only structural, because the fact is that if we are serious about achieving climate goals, we will also be forced to radically adjust behavioural patterns and habits regarding the frequency of use of passenger cars. I therefore particularly welcome the proposal to take into account the concept of sustainability in the very title of the strategy, which is ultimately also provided for in the European Parliament resolution on the Green Agreement.  On this basis, I expect that the new strategy will place the social and environmental dimension of the development of mobility and transport in such a way that the latter do not primarily subsoi economic ambitions, but adapt to people and the environment.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – It cannot be disputed that transport-induced air pollution is one of the root causes of climate change and this sector must therefore be involved in the search for a solution. The modes of transport we know today are about to change, and the EU institutions have a significant role to play in developing the directions for these changes. However, it is also important to stress that transport plays a decisive role in our daily lives and is the backbone of the European economy. We must therefore pay particular attention to the EU transport strategy. The strategic documents under development should take into account the differences between Member States in order to offer solutions that do not strengthen secession or lead to new differences between developed and less developed regions of the Union. I believe that there is no one-to-one solution for all, but that there are different solutions to deal with different situations, but which have a common ultimate goal. Secondly, and perhaps most importantly, I would like to say that the burden of the green transition must be proportionate and fair, not impose a new financial burden on citizens. Everyone must contribute to the solution to the extent that it contributes to the development of the problem.

name: Tomasz FRANKOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The free movement of persons, goods and services is one of the cornerstones of Union citizenship. The potential of free movement can be exploited through efficient mobility and transport services. According to the latest data from the European Commission, the transport industry accounts for more than 6% of the EUROPEAN Union's GDP, providing employment for almost 13 million people.  In the country where I come from – in Poland – transport accounts for about 9% of national GDP, generating around EUR 30 billion (PLN 125 billion) in gross value added. It is undoubtedly one of the most important sectors of the EU economy. In the light of the ambitious challenges facing the full implementation of the Green Deal, the European Union should give priority to the preparation of short-term and long-term transport and mobility strategies. There is no doubt that reducing CO2 and other greenhouse gas emissions requires the involvement of all of us legislators, businesses and citizens. Given the challenges facing European entrepreneurs, the European Union should also clearly define funds for sectoral transformations that foster market protection and innovation. Only then will we be able to achieve climate results in conjunction with the prosperity and protection of European companies.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – The success of the European Green Agreement is in the common interest of all of us. An essential component of this is the development of a fair and sustainable mobility strategy. There are three conditions for success, in my opinion. The first is an appropriate interpretation of the concept of sustainability. In addition to the ecological component, sustainable development has an economic and social dimension. Therefore, in developing the strategy, in addition to climate ambitions, particular attention should be paid to the impact of the measures on jobs and competitiveness. The second is to respect the principle of technology neutrality. The Member States of the Union have different capabilities and transport infrastructures. In order to make them sustainable, we need all the environmentally friendly technologies we need. Finally, responsible action is needed with the complexity of the challenge in mind. In doing so, we should also rely on existing technological solutions and established industries. Such a good example is bioetanol, which, in addition to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, plays an important role in rural development and improving economic competitiveness.

name: Julie LECHANTEUX
text: In writing. The Commission's proposals on mobility and transport to reduce CO2 emissions by 2030 are very ambitious, but we must face reality. This is what I did last November, when I visited in Lyon the most important international exhibition of road and urban transport solutions, Solutrans, where I was able to exchange with professionals in the road freight sector, the backbone of our economy. Today, 98% of industrial vehicles sold in France run on diesel. A change in model will require the adoption of flagship measures. We need to support companies in converting their fleets, whether to electric, gas or hydrogen. Investments must be made in the development of charging infrastructure, financial assistance to communities and individual contractors, adapting the regulations on the total allowable weight in circulation for green vehicles, promoting the movement of clean vehicles in urban areas, promoting the dynamic charging system, encouraging the long-distance charging project and finally, developing the training of new professions in this field. These are concrete solutions!

name: Rovana PLUMB
text: in writing. – Transport and mobility services employ around 11 million people, and the demand for mobility today is higher than ever. However, transport today generates air pollution, noise, congestion and road accidents. The sector already represents almost a quarter of Europe’s greenhouse gas emissions and its emission footprint is rising. We need to prioritise clean and affordable alternatives, with an objective to have only zero emission vehicles on EU roads and make the best use of digital technologies to help reduce fuel consumption. Likewise, the EU’s satellite navigation systems contribute to reducing emissions, for instance in aviation and road transport. As part of this new strategy, the cities and citizens have an important role to play, through sustainable urban planning and addressing mobility demands and infrastructure. Urban areas should also be assisted in digitisation, automation and other innovative solutions and should pursue active and shared transport, from more walking and cycling to car-sharing services and car-pooling. More can and should be done from using recycled content in vehicles and transport infrastructure to reaching more circularity. For example, increasing the collection and recycling rates of electric car batteries in the EU could reduce dependence on imported raw-materials and help to retain the value of recovered materials in the EU economy.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: in writing. – The overall challenge of the European Mobility and Transport agenda was always to enhance the system’s sustainability and competitiveness while satisfying the evolving mobility needs of society. It is thus essential to take a common approach on standards, rules and practices. Unfortunately, so far, little has been done to harmonise the rules concerning the least protected and vulnerable group of road users – pedestrians, including people with disabilities or elderly people, who are one of the main victims of road accidents. In light of some Member States’ legislations, for instance the Polish one, the pedestrian has the priority when he or she is already on the road while in Scandinavia and in the majority of Western European countries pedestrians are protected and have priority even before entering the lanes. Experts and representatives of Polish NGOs like The City is Ours (Miasto jest Nasze) or Critical Walking Mass (Piesza Masa Krytyczna) agree that harmonising laws among the EU by introducing a general provision that would give priority to pedestrians as soon as they intend to enter lanes would increase safety on roads and – consequently – would reduce the number of potential road accidents involving pedestrians.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance, in accordance with Rule 172 of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, as a representative of the capital city of Prague, the capital of the Czech Republic, I would like to say that the Czech Republic and Prague respectively have joined the call by European cities for the European Commission to prepare a European regulation of short-term rentals, the so-called 'short-term rentals'. Airbnb, and I wanted to call on the European Commission here to start tinging this problem at European level.  Today, most European cities have a major problem with short-term commercial rents, which lead to our European cities being depopulated in the centres, creating an unjustified form of business that harms hotel owners and classic formally registered accommodation. I call on the Commission to start addressing this issue, because it will be better to have one European central regulation and not partisan legislation that will not be so effective.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: "If you look at what's left, if you peel off these hate things, we've listed: the non-Hungarians, the others, the migrants, the Roma, the I don't know what, then there's a terrifying formation in the middle. These white, Christian, heterosexual men and women are among them. This outrageous, racist statement, which was just quoted literally, is that white, Christian, heterosexual people are a frightening formation, made recently by the Vice-President of the DK party belonging to the European Socialists, a former MEP of the S&D group.  The DK leader's statement is grossly racist. It is unacceptable for anyone to be stigmatised for their skin colour, religion or sexual orientation. We strongly reject the fact that the majority of people in Europe are being racially and inciterably desicicable. Klára Dobrev, a Vice-President of the European Parliament, is also a dk politician. We therefore expect a clear answer from Klara Dobrev when he will be willing, as well as the Democratic Coalition and the Group of the European Socialists, to publicly distance himself from the racist statement of his party colleague.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, this will probably be my final speech in this Parliament, so can I begin by – through you, President – thanking the Parliament staff and their services and indeed my own staff as well, who’ve been truly brilliant through a difficult period of uncertainty. One of my biggest regrets is that as a student, as a young person, I didn’t do an Erasmus exchange and I really wish that I had. In many ways, I feel my time in this Parliament has been like my Erasmus exchange, which sadly now comes to an end, and I want to use this, probably my final words in this Parliament, to encourage young people to take those opportunities that the Erasmus programme offers. I intend to continue to campaign to ensure those opportunities are still there for all young people in the UK, and that means continued and full participation in Erasmus programmes in the future. Brexit, in my view, is a historic mistake. It will come with costs and consequences. Those consequences must not damage the chances and opportunities of the next generation. But I fear they will. We must now do all we can to make sure they don’t. So, thank you, and for now, from me, farewell and good luck.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, the independence of justice and respect for human rights are fundamental elements for the future of Europe. Citizens' confidence in the European Union is sure to ensure the future of Europe. But what do we do when we have states where justice is not independent, where justice decisions violate human rights?  I will give a very concrete example, I come back with this example: the case of the Simimal family. Our Romanian woman, a doctor in Finland, who for three years has been parted with children in an odious way. The children were mistreated. You can see the video on YouTube and you'll see the masks lift the children, who are suing from the mother's arms. These children are traumatized: two brothers, who were separated from their mother, and each other. Now, recently, in November, they ran away. Why did they run away from the state institution?  What is Europe doing? How do children and the rights of the child not be respected, because behold, they have turned 12, and Mary, and Michael, and have no right to appear in court to make their point. On behalf of Camelia Simicala, on behalf of her two children, please also, Commissioner, because she is a Romanian woman of ours, make the children come home with their mother.

name: Valter FLEGO
text: - Dear Vice-Presidents, the 2021 budget by 2027 must be visionary, there must be a bold budget that stimulates innovation and research, fosters ecology and green policies and absolutely boosts digitalisation. While driverless taxis are already running in the U.S. on the one hand, we're casced. We are dragging our time on launching programmes that are essential for a competitive, successful Europe and all Member States.  As rapporteur of the Digital Europe programme, I tell you that the race has already started, and digital Europe is one of our key competitors or favorites in the global race. That is why I ask the Council to bring us a budget as soon as possible, to present us with a budget that will have the determination and wisdom to say no to cutting, to the financial cutting of such programmes as digital Europe that can contribute to greater competitiveness of the European economy, but also to a better standard of living for all our citizens.

name: Francisco GUERREIRO
text: – Madam President, four years ago at COP 22, Prime Minister Portuguese, Dr António Costa, committed himself to achieving carbon neutrality in 2050. He even said that one of his priorities was to drastically reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the transport sector. But contrary to the announcement, the government Portuguese is moving forward today to the construction of a commercial airport in Montijo. It thus advances without the support of civil society, without an environmental impact assessment, without considering the impacts on the reservations of the Tagus estuary, without studies of tourist capacity and without studying the complementary option of Beja airport. In fact, the best justification given by the government to reject the already built and paid airport beja is that it is – and I quote – far away. We assume that it is very far from the capital but, dear and dear friends, neither this is true nor Portugal comes down to Lisbon.

name: Maria WALSH
text: – Madam President, under the European VAT Directive, sun cream is not listed as a product eligible for a reduced VAT rate. This desperately needs to change. Irish Senator Tim Lombard has proposed that, in an effort to tackle skin cancer and make sun cream more available, we need to remove VAT on it. Sun cream is classed as a luxury product in this day and age. My group, the European People’s Party, recently launched our new campaign to ensure the fight against cancer is a top priority in the European Union over the next five years. Disease prevention must be high on the European agenda. I intend to raise this issue with our Health Commissioner and ask for the utmost support in categorising sun cream as a pharmaceutical product for use for health care, and not a luxury product. I believe we need to take a holistic approach to well-being to ensure our Europeans, our citizens have optimum physical and mental health. Prevention for any illness, be it cancer or mental health – which is a priority for my mandate – is a tool that must be used to help everyone’s health and well-being.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, today, as a month ago, we discussed the situation in Greece, but we must also give solutions. And solutions need to be given in the long term because migration is a phenomenon that will last many years from now. There are three things that need to be done.  Firstly, Mr Borrell must negotiate readmission agreements with all countries that are the source of illegal migration. Secondly, Mr Borrell must negotiate cooperation with transit countries so that organised crime groups moving these people towards boats on the shores of the Mediterranean are neutralised. And finally, the third point to be resolved: military fleet ships to return boats carrying illegal migrants to the port from which they left.

name: Julie LECHANTEUX
text: Madam President, on 23 November and 1 December 2019, in my department, the Var, floods of unexpected magnitude caused several deaths and serious injuries, with significant physical and psychological damage. The bad weather caused material damage worth hundreds of millions of euros, all on the eve of the commemoration of the 60th anniversary of the Malpasset dam disaster, which killed 423 people. We know that the Var is a risk zone. Unfortunately, it must be noted that the flood prevention action programme, the famous PAPI, has always remained at the stage of words and studies and has never translated into concrete actions. In the face of this scandalous inertia of the French government, I therefore believe that the time has come to immediately mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund in order to do the necessary work to ensure the security of the territory, in order to protect the population from these natural disasters.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, there is now a strategy in Portugal to attack the National Health Service for the offensive against health professionals and a systemic shortfall in investment in resources and infrastructure. The doors to the privatization of health have opened up, making it a highly profitable business for economic groups. This offensive aligns with the impositions and constraints of the European Union, which do not serve the country. The country recommendations under the European Semester insist on health spending cuts when what is urgent is more investment to meet the needs of people from north to south in the various health units and valences, in their central or proximity response. A free and quality National Public Health Service, as enshrined in the Constitution of the Portuguese Republic, is what serves the country. This means that the interests of the country must be put ahead of the interests of the European Union.

name: Belinda DE LUCY
text: – Madam President, I may be happy today that democracy is finally being implemented in the UK, but I am also very sad. I’m sad at the UK taking a path that is incompatible with democracy. I loved how the nations united around trade after the Second World War. For us it was good, it was hopeful, it was positive, but it has morphed it has morphed into something very different that labels criticism as populism, that needs to steal democratic agency from people in order to run smoothly. This is not a recipe for peace that I recognise, and I just pray that you self-reflect after we leave. Please do not treat democracy like an obstacle that you need to navigate around for efficiency. The smooth running of the EU should not come at the cost of democratic agency for your people. Please, please take heed. We do not leave in a way that is unfriendly, and it’s not as if we want bad relations. We love Europe; Brexit was never a rejection of Europe. We are your friends and we wish to remain your friends.

name: Radan KANEV
text: – Today in the cities of Bulgaria thousands of representatives of small and medium-sized businesses protested. They protested against bureaucratic arbitrariness, against the ever-increasing administrative and tax burden, against unfair and discriminatory forms of taxation, against daily party-political pressure and legal uncertainty reminiscent of the long-gone times of the communist regime. They protested despite the government's attempts to once again delay their fair discontent with empty promises.  The European institutions are in debt to small business, which provides the jobs and economic growth of Europe that got us out of the economic crisis. Our small business support strategies and programmes must come out of the realm of wishes and become real, effective guarantees, in real protection from the arbitrariness of bureaucrats and self-forgotten powermen.

name: Lina GÁLVEZ MUÑOZ
text: – Madam President, I would like to speak in this House today to talk about Andalusia, the European Green Pact and also mobility. I want to talk about the Doñana National Park, a biosphere reserve and the most biodiversity-rich space in Europe and also a world heritage site.  The Andalusian Government has announced that it will tender for the construction of a third, apparently reversible, lane on the road between Matalascañas and Almonte, in the Doñana Natural Park. While it is true that this project is in high demand and that it can improve road safety, it is necessary to see very well how it is implemented and materialized. We are talking about an extremely environmentally sensitive area.  A few months ago, the Government of Andalusia announced a plan that planned to build a highway in Doñana. I then addressed a question to the European Commission, which responded clearly by saying that it would be vigilant for that highway not to be built. In this sense I believe that this new project should also be closely monitored.  I would also like to take this opportunity to put on the table the need to continue to delve into the debate on mobility and the tourism model in a national park.

name: Radka MAXOVÁ
text: – Madam President, on Sunday 16 January there was a huge tragedy in the Czech Republic. Eight people died in the fire at the home for people with disabilities in Vejprtech, and another 30 had to be hospitalized. I want to offer my deepest condolences to the bereaved and to thank all those who have prevented further deaths and injuries with the dedicated life of their lives. It's important to think about the cause of the fire.  In the Czech Republic, the transformation of social services has almost stopped. It ceased to be a social and political issue. People with disabilities often live in non-compliant large-scale institutions, do not receive sufficient individual support, and often their dependence on care is deepened. This is often linked to staff shortages and inadequate and unpredictable funding of social services. The situation is similar in other Member States. This is not the direction in which the European Union should go. It is these days that the European Parliament is preparing a resolution on a post-2020 strategy for persons with disabilities. I call on us to approach this document with all seriousness and responsibility.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Madam President, I will once again refer to a subject that we discussed today, Brexit. I believe that on this day, in addition to the immediate effects that Britain's departure from the European Union will have, we need to think about the 3.5 million European citizens who are in the UK labour market.  Among the 3.5 million Europeans are more than 450,000 Romanian citizens. I believe that future relations between Brussels and London must focus, have as a priority that our citizens are respected, that there is no discrimination whatsoever. I have high hopes for the Commission's ability to defend our freedoms and the principles underlying our Union, such as freedom of movement, freedom of movement, freedom of work, to be respected and put in the spotlight in the negotiations ahead in the coming year.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Madam President, first of all, a special greeting on a day like today to my colleagues Richard Corbett, Julie Ward, Jude Kirton-Darling and Claude Moraes.  Secondly, I would like to use this intervention to denounce before this House and the European public opinion - and to inform the Commission of this – a serious initiative taken by the party of the Spanish far-right Vox in the Murcia region with the so-called 'parental veto', which aims to restrict the participation of children in complementary activities which they believe they should not receive. I mean gender equality, sexual orientation or citizenship education.  This is very serious that we must also fight from the European public sphere and I hope that the Commission and most of the political groups in the House will help us.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Madam President! Thank you very much. It was very emotional in this building today, we were talking about the past, about what went wrong a few decades ago – I am talking about Auschwitz – and what went wrong a few years ago – I am talking about the UNITED Kingdom that is really leaving us on Friday.  A lot of things have gone wrong and we have a lot to learn from this past. For? For the sake of the future, because there is still a lot of wrong things and I do not dare to predict what will happen to this singy Conference on the Future of Europe.  But it is probably clear to all of us, I hope, that people are rightly disappointed and we must give them the opportunity to participate, which is what is most important here: the participation of citizens. Even if less is done, let it be done the way it goes, not to do something half-way or to do nothing at all in the end.  Colleagues and colleagues, Abraham Lincoln once said, and I will finish this. In the original, I'm going to say, "The best way to predict our future is to create it." Thanks.

name: Pernando BARRENA ARZA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow in Euskal Herria — in the Autonomous Community of the Basque Country and the Foral Community of Navarra — a call for a general strike will take place in defence of pensions and decent working and living conditions for workers in general. This strike is inspired by the great mobilizations of pensioners and the initiative of the Community Charter of Social Rights, which advocates building a different socio-product model, which puts life at the centre, giving priority to the care of people and the sustainability of the planet.  We want to show our support for this call and urge the Commission to pursu measures to ensure that States implement pensions and living minimum wages, guarantee the right to return to work alive and eliminate the pay gap, implement the 35-hour working day, eliminate social cuts, bet on public services and establish social clauses in all administrative procurements.  The rights we enjoyed today were not given to us by anyone. They were achieved through struggle and mobilization, and tomorrow, no doubt, there will be a new opportunity to defend and improve them.

name: Peter POLLÁK
text: – Madam President, these days we commemorate the victims who lost their lives during the Second World War and their lives turned into ashes. Millions of people paid with their lives because of a Nazi ideology that divided people into superhumans and subhumans. The ashes of Jews, Roma, Slavs and other Europeans were mixed in the furnaces of concentration camps. They all paid equally with their lives for peace in Europe. It is unacceptable that we are now quietly looking at - as fascists have taken off their uniforms, put on their clothes, attached to their sails and are sitting in democratic institutions today, even in this House. Nazism and fascism have nothing to do with freedom and democracy. It's a crime. It's the seed of absolute hell, it has nothing to do with God, it's the work of the devil. The fight against intolerance, the fight against Nazism and fascism must also be seduced because it is a debt to those who died during the Second World War. I ask the European Commission, the European Council, the European Parliament and all democratic institutions, including in the Member States of the European Union, to urgently stop all those who spread hatred and promote Nazism and fascism.

name: Isabel GARCÍA MUÑOZ
text: – Madam President, before the deniers of climate change, Gloria passed through Spain, with heavy rains, wind, waves and brutal snowfalls that left thousands of people in my region, Aragon, isolated and whose thaw now threatens many populations by overflowing rivers. Nearly 4,000 kilometres of roads and 142 municipalities in the provinces of Zaragoza and Teruel have been affected, with thousands of people incommunicado, without electricity or water, without internet connection or coverage; there has also been damage to buildings and ships and serious losses in the countryside and livestock. Cooperation between the central and regional governments has been essential and, together with security forces, the EME and regional emergency services, town halls and neighbours are working to respond to the exceptionality experienced. An exceptionality which further highlights the need to work from the European institutions, together with national, regional and local authorities, for territorial and socio-economic cohesion and to seek solutions to the challenges of these rural and mountainous areas, which are also suffering from depopulation and the urgent need to improve their transport and telecommunications infrastructures.

name: Andrea CAROPPO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on 22 January, thousands of VAT numbers in Italy left businesses closed and took to the streets of Rome to protest and to say enough, especially with regard to unfair taxation and a vexatious tax. A total taxation of more than 60 % and which is forcing many activities to close down. Suffice it to say that, over the last few years, the number of small and medium-sized enterprises and professionals has fallen by almost 40 %. In 2018, Italians paid 33 billion more in taxes than the European average and it is a differential that weighs almost 2 % on GDP. It is clear that what is happening in Italy jeopardises the fairness of tax systems in the Member States and the growth policy of the entire European Union. That is why it is essential for the Commission to intervene and to grant greater flexibility to Italy in order to avoid the end and, above all, the death of the VAT numbers of this world, which is the productive fabric of Italy.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Madam President, last Monday, a Minister of the Spanish Social Community Government went at midnight to Barajas Airport clandestinely to meet – and avoid his arrest – with Delcy Rodríguez, vice-president of The Maduro dictatorship in Venezuela, a criminal subject to European Union sanctions, which prohibits her entry into Europe.  We know that the dictatorship has funded Spanish communists, we know that former socialist President Zapatero is the main defender of criminal drug addicting. The communists funded by this drug addict are now in the Spanish government.  The European Union must investigate the background of this very serious violation of the European Union's own sanctions against Caracas criminals by this Spanish social-community government.

name: John David Edward TENNANT
text: – Madam President, as Britain prepares for life outside our membership of this Union, I thought I would reflect on just how damaging this Union has been for my country. You say that the Union has been good for democracy. I fail to see how democratic this place is, while governed by unelected, largely unaccountable bureaucrats no one has ever heard of. You say this Union has been good for jobs and industry. Well, that’s a laugh and a half: in my region, the steel industry has collapsed, leading to huge job losses due to state-aid legislation that this place has imposed. You say that the Union is value—for—money, yet Britain has been contributing the second—highest amount to the EU, and you continue the traveling circus to Strasbourg every month at a cost of roughly EUR 114 million a year. But listen carefully: Brexit is a warning shot to many of you, who blindly ignore the public who view you as wasteful, ignorant and distant. If you do not learn the lessons of Britain’s departure from this House of largesse, you will consign yourselves to the dustbin of history.

name: Tsvetelina PENKOVA
text: – Dear Madam President, honourable Members, the European Commission has repeatedly stated that the governments of the Member States must draw up a detailed strategy for the implementation of the European Green Pact. The fact is that some countries and regions in Europe will be more affected by the implementation of these policies, and I think it is essential to know what the social dimensions of the future transition to a low-carbon economy will be. We need to have a clear idea of how we can transform our economy so that everyone can benefit from this change, and for that we need a clear and long-term strategy prepared by the governments of the Member States.  The ecological transition is an economic and social opportunity for every region in Europe. The Green Pact is a complete transformation of the European economy and should not be seen as another solution imposed by Brussels. We should all be the engine of this plan for the future, not just passive observers.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: Madam President, I met David at a mobilization, right outside, on social security and he told me about the fact that, in his sector, with the fact that some companies, say a Romanian company that temporarily sends a worker to Belgium; then, social security contributions are paid at the rate of the sending country, thus that of Romania. And this is problematic because, in a competitive logic, this company has a competitive advantage over Belgian companies, in particular, and it becomes an excuse for governments, such as the Belgian government, to impose reductions in social security contributions on Belgian companies in the name of competitiveness. The workers of the blow are the turkeys of farce, because they lose in gross wages and they lose in social security so a very clear question for the European Commission: can we please impose the highest, most favourable social contribution rate for workers and social security; And when? Because workers need it, thank you.

name: Robert ROWLAND
text: – Mr President, the Brussels hierarchy wants the EU to be a superpower. Well it has achieved that in one sense: it is a regulatory superpower. On that score, it has got no global peer. The whole raison d’être of the EU is regulation. It is a form of directive economics but has the advantage of not being paid for by taxation, as the costs are borne by businesses and passed on to consumers. Regulation is really a subspecies of central planning.  What shocks me is how Europe has developed economically: it is truly status, where only large multinationals thrive due to crony capitalism. Its attitude to business in general, start—ups, innovation in the sciences and technology and the sheer scale of regulation have been anti-competitive, anti-growth and job-destroying. So, as we leave the EU, I believe the economic consequences will be hugely positive for the UK – not least through regaining our regulatory autonomy and the ability to do our own free—trade deals. We should strive to become Singapore on terms the EU fears so much.  So I warn you: as I look forward to the EU’s prospects for 2020, I see negative interest rates, the start of QE once again and a (microphone clicks) state of the economy. So please watch and be careful, because your economy is in tatters.
